reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love Interstellar Marines!!!
It's currently a game in progress but totally worth getting right now.

Several types of game play:

Playground
Single player
Co-op
Multiplayer
Hell Week

Maps:

Maps are dynamic, anamorphic and dirty unlike other FPS games.

In Breif:

Dynamic elements:
Ever changing light and weather conditions. These change at random intervals and the associated sounds increase the realizm of the moment. One moment a gentle breeze and sunny skies, the darkness rolls in with hard wind and driving rain, a short while later... Darkness falls and silence... A flashlight or walking could give you away...

Anamorphic elements:
Most other FPS maps are quite static with maybe a door or a window to break to achieve an objective. In ISM many maps physically change often causing you to reroute to achieve an objective. Matched with everchanging environmental variables this is quite engaging.

Dirty elements:
I love the fact that the physical ripples of water motion can give away a creeping enemy. You hide in long blades of tall grass or have ferns providing disguising you for an unaware opponent.
Tracking a target that runs into a bush and still nailing him; but they run behind a tree and you miss... A missed shot can give you away. Sometimes you're in a combination bushes grass and trees, you might be spotted and shot at. They might hit or miss depending on that coverage. It's harder to hit what you can't clearly see...
This provides a better sense of realism than other POP FPS games with maps that have clear sightlines in all directions and no cover.

Currently there are 3 guns:

Pistol with ironsight
Submachine gun with dot sight x2 zoom
Battle rifle with ACOG x4 zoom

All are equipped with Flashlights Suppressors and Lazers.
Each have different fire rates, damages and accuracies.

Fresh free content on an almost monthly basis with huge updates quarterly to semi annually.

The Dev's:
ISM Devs are all approachable and easy to talk to.
There's an event every Monday/Tuesday where the dev's join into a public game and interact directly with the players. Don't miss out! They even have a teamspeak channel for all to speak freely.

I'll most more as ISM evolves. Don't pass up on this great game!
voteText: 20 of 36 people (56%) found this review helpful 4 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A genuinely tense gaming experience without resorting to cheap jumpscares... and it's not even really a horror game.  The devs are active within the community and if you join the steam community group you'll be notified about the community events where one of the devs livestreams the game on twitch, talks to players on teamspeak, and everyone has a really good time so be sure to check that out.

One thing people forget when commenting on how incomplete an early access game is, is how much opportunity there is to give feedback at a time where it can actually be implemented into the game.  It's obvious the team is very passionate and dedicated to finishing this game so I'm not worried about that like with some others on early access.

reviewerDisplayName: Never died in a videogame ever
reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is looking like a very promising space-shooter. I purchased the spearhead edition of the game because I thought it was very cool how the developers promised to put your name in the credits. It also comes with an extra copy of the game which you can send to a friend, as well as the game's soundtrack and concept art. Interstellar Marines is different from other shooters in a really cool way. Dynamic environments. Every few minutes or so the weather,lighting or structure of the map itself will change. I like this because it forces you to switch up strategies depending on the condition of the battlefield. The changing environments will affect your combat behavior as well as the behavior of your enemies. Barriers will be erected, the game will go dark or flash red emergency lights. It's kinda reminded me of paintball in a lot of ways. You can be eliminated quickly, but if you are strategic enough, you can prevail.

I can't wait when this game is released in its final form.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

ISM is a great take on the old tactical FPS genre. It punishes head-long derp rushes a la Halo, GOW, or Unreal Tournament, instead rewarding careful movement, foresight, tactical analysis, and a steady ♥♥♥♥-you gun hand. While in it's current state (Update 10 as of this writing) feels sort of limited (one gun, no customization, missing several features of other FPS game like sprinting or melee), the gunplay is solid, the movement is slick, the graphics as beautiful (especially on ultra. Dat Pc Master Race), and the maps are amazing (Pitch black? Do you dare risk the flashlight for some clear sight that everyone else can see? Turn on the laser sight for some accurate hipfire at the expense of everyone seeing where the ♥♥♥♥ you are? Decisions, decisions!).

I can't recommend this as a full game, not in it's current state. But as an Early Access game?

♥♥♥♥ yeah.

Get in here, Marine. Training starts in five.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI don't even have to be saying this, go buy this game! This is one of the most intense and immersive FPS ive played, it has amazing potential and is just hellafun, I HAVE NEVER HAD THIS MUCH FUN WITH AN !EARLY ACCSES GAME! The maps are amazing, the way the enviornment and sounds works make it feel real. I love the weather, usually in games like minecraft i would hate the rain, but i absolutly love it when it rains in this game, its amazing. And in most games, the sound is somtimes overlooked by users, one of the many things that stands out about this game is the sounds, you CANT play this game and not stop to enjoy the sounds of rain patting down on barricades... even if you just got shot in the head. I pat the men and women on the back who put those sounds in the game. The controls are very smooth and the character animations are great! One thing that also stands out is the lack of a HUD, usually in FPS's you have your health, amunition, and energy all just stuck to your face, in Interstellar Marines you are looing through a simple dang fancey lookin helmet, nothing to break the immersion. And the way they did the helmet ammo display is awesome, also if you press h you can lift up your helmet, making for an amazing immersive experience that i havent seen in another game. Overall i highly reccomend INTERSTELLAR MARINES and i love where its going. And in this game, if you play your cards right, you CAN be a one man army.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nInterstellar Marines. In it's current form is very entertaining and fulfilling experience after you understand the mechanics underlying everything. Now, the game does suffer from poor framerates for the average computer and tanks my FPS with AA applied. Being that this is Update 10 it's to be expected. Now, this game brings some serious game changers to the FPS scene. You have variable environments mid level, meaning that you have daylight, rain, red alerts, or pitch black and likely more to come. Then you have actual movement mechanics, aiming mechanics, and cover system. This game has a large potential to blow up in popularity in later stages of development and I wholeheartedly look forward to whats to come. Recommended.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I thought I would edit my review, seeing as I had been playing it a bit more over the past few days.

Interstellar Marines still is very much in Early Access, and has been for as long as I can remember, seeing it pop up on Kickstarter some years ago. Though fear not, though we've had some shaky EA games recently, the attention to detail and updates coming to this game show no sign of slowing down. We received a campaign type map mode to play either singleplayer or cooperatively, there's also another more linear map that can be played singleplayer or cooperatively, and then there are the whole host of survival and extinction maps to play either singleplayer or cooperatively. This is all on top of the previous PvP game mode that was already implemented.

The coop and singleplayer have you facing against both armed and unarmed CTRs, or Combat Training Robots. There is a small bug where when you kill an armed one it still comes up saying unarmed, and it says +15 points for killing one when you only get 5; but they're minor issues.

The dev team at Zero Point Software really know how to do atmosphere. In some of the survival modes, near the end of the sequence the whole map goes pitch black, you HAVE to use your flashlight. Of course, this means you can only see in the direction you're facing, it also means that when you reload the light points into the air somewhat as it's an underbarrel mounted flashlight. This makes for super intense moments when you can hear the unarmed CTRs running towards you, but have no idea where they are.

The environments are also amazing, the rain and effect it leaves on your helmet visor, the fog, the alarm lighting, and just the areas you're dropped into in general. Definitely a fantastic game, if you ever see it in a bundle, I would buy it without question as you will not regret it, even the Steam store asking price isn't bad for what you're getting, especially with the stream and quality of updates.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First impressions: I love it.

Looks: a lot of post-processing going on, and without it I'd say it would look along the lines of Half-Life 2. Runs smoothly, looks very immersive with its dynamic weather and small touches like the raindrops hitting the helmet. The helmet itself features a HUD and if you lift the helmet up it's a HUDless view. A few graphical bugs here and there, but nothing gamebreaking at all; things like your gun disappearing into the wall if you stand too close, or snow falling through walls.

Gameplay: plays like a tactical Source game, with aim down sights and sprinting. A lot of emphasis on the sound around you, and the environment plays a big part in the gameplay, like when lights dim and you're forced to use your flashlight, while exposing your position in doing so. At the moment there is only one gun to use, so everything is balanced, and the hitboxes are fair.

Overall, it's a very fun game with a level of immersion you rarely see in shooters. It almost seems like a finished product, yet it's only in alpha stage. Very interested to see what the devs make of it over the coming months.

Amazing Graphics delivered with a unreal briliance mixed, with amazing ambient (visual or graphical) powered by brilliant innovating minds that created this 3D Surreal First Person Shooter and so on for some time.

Worth the triple price i've paid for the Spearhead Edition.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Below you'll find both a video and written impression of the game.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-W7IknKx0YE

Interstellar Marines may come off as a generic tactical shooter upon first impressions, but once you start playing, you'll see that this game has a few interesting mechanics that helps separate this game from the plethora of other tactical FPSs on the market. The game features a very interesting, and realistic lighting system, where some times the map will put players into total darkness. This will force players to start using their flashlight which will of course give them away to enemy fire. Certainly an interesting take on a risk-reward system for a tactical FPS. The game also features mid-match dynamic level alterations. The game map will change, closing and opening new choke points and paths, mid match, in real time. This has a dynamic effect on the game field. Lastly the game features a ridiculous amounts of capture points in it's game mode. This came off as a negative, almost as a design flaw at first, but the more I played I saw what the designer had in mind. This tactical shooter encourages spiting up and covering ground, rather than the usual, 7 man in a choke point cluster F*** that the usual tactical shooter tend to lean towards.

The game's audio, and visual is impressive, and it's attention to detail as well as it's lighting is equally so.

The game is not with out it's faults though. In it's current stage of early access, there is no single player campaign, minimal tutorial, only one game mode, and only the default rifles hurt this game's variety. The game also has some net code issues as it has noticeable and undeniable bullet lag. Interstellar Marines also face the hurdle of developing a robust and active community, in the face of hundreds if not thousands of other tactical shooters, fighting for the same audience. Currently the game's community is active, but relatively small. Only 1-3 servers will any sort of population at any given time, or even less.

But overall, Interstellar Marines is a very enjoyable game that has a pile of potential! I think the game should change it's name as it's incredibly generic, and also promote it's unique light and dark play more to help interest more people.

Pros:
- Unique Light / Dark mechanic
- Unique mid-game battlefield transformation mechanic
- Impressive visuals, especially the lighting
- Very enjoyable and playable, even as an early access

Cons:
- Needs more variety
- Net code needs a lot of working out
- Needs to build a larger community

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First of all what you need to know is that as of right now when im writing this review (22-1-2015) the game is still in the Pre Alpha Stage of development and that it is developed by an Indie Studio. So it is far from being completed (But that is also why this game is in Early Access)

However the developers are very dedicated, friendly and active on the forums and ingame, so there is already a very strong, very friendly but kinda small community in the game.

The overall feel they are trying to make the game have is inspired by the games:

Half Life, System Shock 2 and the Rainbow Six series. (they are aiming for a tactical and immersive shooter)

If I should describe the game I guess the closest I can come to it is this:

This game is what Aliens Colonial Marines should have been and Insurgency in space.

So for an Early Access game, it is amazing and I'm really looking forward to see how this game develops in the future, I really have high hopes for this one :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early Access Summary:
Gameplay: 9
Music: 10
Sound: 9
Graphics: 7
Community: 7
Devs: 9
Overall Review of Early Access: 8/10
System Requirements: Anything made in the last 5 years, excluding chromebooks

Full Early Access Review:
One of the best Tactical Shooters on Steam right now. Incredibly immersive, the sound, lighting, and level design is top notch. Content wise, the game is slowly growing, with more multiplayer maps every couple updates, and more singleplayer every couple months.
Eventually, the devs have promised (And I don't doubt they will deliver) a full co-op campaign, with RPG elements. Considering the game is already my favorite co-op experience besides Payday 2, I'd say Interstellar Marines could be THE co-op game for the next few years. The Dev's have Twitch broadcasts quite often, and are also very active on the forums. (At their website, not as much on steam)
The game is well worth the $15, but I went all out and got Spearhead. I refuse to pre-order or buy early access to almost all games, but this is definitely worth it.

Score: 8/10.
Wins the Sorrowful Award for Legitness.
Buy it now, or if you are hesitant, buy it on sale.
Either way, you won't be dissapointed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

NOTE: THIS IS A FANBOY REVIEW!!This review was made in 2013. I was quite the fanboy of the game back then. I may update this review to fit the games current state and to get rid of my past fanboyism.

I understand that some people think that this game sucks because you can't jump (which you can now), crouch, there's only one weapon ATM.
But hey! How many shooting weapons did Mario have in the first Mario game? One! (The fireball) Was it a bad game? Not it was really fun and it still is! (I know cause I have it for the NES :-D)

So why is that relevant? That is because it's just features! You don't even need these features for a game to be fun! I understand that some people have standards these days because every FPS game include loads of weapons and stuff but in the end: You don't need it to have fun! Simple games can be fun! Remember Minecraft in alpha? That was really simple but still really fun!

Also! This is a game somewhere between alpha and pre-alpha so what did you expect? You're not seppose to expect games with a lot of content if you buy games on Early Access!


Now! Since this is a somewhat review I guess I gotta say my overall opinion about the game and stop telling people why they are wrong about the game.
I will review this while keeping in mind that it is in alpha.

Interstellar Marines is a really fun game if you get together with some guys in a match. It can be challenging if you're new to the game but it doesn't take much time to get the hang of it.
The graphics are pretty decent for an indie title.
The game runs smoothly even at 40 FPS (I have a hard time playing other games at 40 FPS).
The maps are fun and exciting and there are many ways to trick or storm your enemy with many entry points, hiding places and sniping positions.
The maps also have this really amazing dynamic weather system where it changes the weather a few times while playing a match. Some times it gets really foggy and other times it gets so dark that you can't see anything without the flashlight on but if you turn it on you will reveal your position to the enemy. I personally think that the darkness in this game is one of the most amazing things in a game. My heart always starts pumping of excitment when it gets dark and this is one of those few games that arn't scared of the dark cause I've seen a lot of games with dark level where you can just barly see without a flashlight but in this game it's a different story! Which adds some realism and immersion to the game.

I got a little ahead of my self with that darkness talking so let's just get to the pros and cons.

Pros:
+ Playable at 40 FPS
+ Fun and challenging
+ Dynamic weather
+ Amazing darkness
+ Decent graphics
+ Great maps for tactical opportunities
(+) One really unice map that changes the height of it's floors while playing
+ Fun gamemode (Domination like)
+ Nice sound
+ Singleplayer room made for players to test the new features

Cons:
- Only one playable gamemode even though they've made two
- None of their two singeplayer modes from the official site in the game
- No connection to your user made on the official site
- Progress feels kinda slow

(I didn't like to write that last con because I'm a fan of the game and I understand why it's going slowly but it doesn't change the fact that it's going slowly)

So this is my review of Interstellar Marines in it's current version (version 7).
Since this is a game in alpha state I might make a new review of it when it's fully released cause you can't really rate a product that isn't done yet. If this was the final release then yes. It would not be worth the money but it is in alpha so I do actually think this is worth the money.


- Martin Schultz / Mtsmts

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Interstellar Marines is a tactical FPS in which two teams of marines are pitted against each other in an underground simulated environment.  Some very unique features of this game include the almost immediate death and the weather mechanics.  This is a game in which the old run n' gun technique will almost always get you killed.  Often the best strategy involves using a suppressor and sneaking around until you can ambush your enemies.

Some subjective and personal positive aspects to the game I have noticed are:

Losing your HUD once you take a certain amount of damage.
In this game's multiplayer it is nearly impossible to tell friendly soldiers from your enemies without the use of your HUD.  The feature which temporarily removes use of your HUD makes being wounded even more frantic because when you turn to run you need to look twice to make sure the marine behind you is friendly.
A feature which closely accompanies the loss of your HUD is the ability to open your helmet.  By pressing H" you are able to completely disengage your display and open your helmet.  This comes in handy when it is raining because the rain will obstruct your vision by sticking to your visor.

Operable doors.
Most FPS these days have decided to remove the idea of operable doors in their multiplayer modes.  I beleive that it is a strong suite for this game they have not decided to do that as well.  When opening a door on a map such as Dynacore you can't tell if some one is hiding on the other side.  Doors are also very useful as cover from enemy fire.  It also adds a degree of realism and dynamic gameplay.

Weather/Day night system.
This game has fully dynamic shadows and a weather system which has been expertly fleshed out.  You have different weather conditions from rain to snow to high winds.  The rain will greatly obstruct your vision while your helmet is down. The snow reduces visibility in general and plays tricks with your mind because of the movement. The winds add slightly more chaos to the area however are likely the least influential of the three.
The day and night rotations are incredibly important in any game of Interstellar Marines.  In the day time you have only a very small chance of successfully hiding.  In the dusk and at night you will have a much easier time at remaining concealed.  You will also learn that the use of a flashlight is unadvisable to say the least.  The dynamic changes in weather and time force players to change their strategies whenever the map decides that it got bored.

Lastly
date:
the dynamic motions of elements in the maps.
Many of the multiplayer maps have different structures of elements within the maps themselves which will periodically move.  This will force players to change their routes and hiding spots as hallways are cut off and buildings rise into the air and sink into the ground.

Now for what I dislike about the game in its current state.  Please be advised everything listed below is subject to change.  Alpha = Alpha

The game has very few weapons at the moment.
I am personally very happy learning to use two different weapons proficiantly.  But for those of us who want more variation you may have a hard time excepting the lack of variety in your choice of weapons.  On top of this there is only a few small differences in the way the two current weapons handle.  The Rifle has more accuracy over the SMG but it quickly loses that with sustained fire.  The SMG has an additional 10 rounds over the Rifle bringing it to a total of 30.  It also has iron sights with a much lower magnification that allows it to be used in close quarters combat
recommended:
as opposed to the 4x scope on the Rifle.  However besides these small differences the guns are essentially identical.

Movement system.
Although perfect in almost all situations
hoursPlayed: the movement system has its flaws.  The devs have nerfed sprinting and jumping by forcing you to start panting after a certain amount of either running or hopping about.  My concerns with this mechanic in its current state are as follows; Jumping rarely allows you to overcome an obstacle the first try.  After your second or third attempt you begin panting for as long as 20 seconds afterwards.  In multiplayer it can also get tiresome when you are trying to catch up with your team on the map Evacuation and you start to pant
voteText:
then you encounter and enemy and your crosshair is bouncing all over the screen.

Early Access.
The game is currently in development.  Listen to me when I say that this game is in EARLY ACCESS.  That means when you buy it you are admitting that this is the product you want in its CURRENT STATE.  Although I think this game deserves all the support it needs to have a successful launch
helpfulPercent: you must understand that there is no guarantee it will ever be released
votesHelpful: and there is no guarentee there will ever be another update.  If you decide to spend your money on this game
votesTotal:
I would say its worth every cent.  But at the same time you must make certain you want this game and not the Interstellar Marines that you are thinking about 5 years down the line.


Please remember this is a preliminary review of an early access game which is subject to change.  Before perchasing you should look at other reviews and perhaps some video coverage of it online.


Thank you

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Although the Devs may take their time with game updates.  I'm grateful for the amount of content that has been released within the past few years. This gets me rather  excited for what is to come upon the next few months. Mostly because of the amount of game content that we have now is rather impressive. The game has multiple modes that such as Single player and  Coop campaign missions, Horde style game modes where players must defend off waves of killer robots,  and the standard multiplayer team deathmatch where players must take over control points in order for their team to win. (  think of it like the Conquest mode from the  battlefield games but on a smaller scale.)  And lets not forget that this game has a hunger games-ish gamemode where players are put against each other  in LARGE maps. The main idea is to be the last man( or woman) to  survive the hour long match. The graphics in this game is great to look at.  the lighting and the sound within this game is just drop dead EXCELLENT.  The sounds of gun shots make the feeling of shooting within the game feel meaningful.  the hunting rawrs the robots make when they spot you from a point of view. With so much good to be said about the game. it does come into some faults. One of the coop maps are bit bugged right now. its a bug that disconnects you from the coop map before you even play it. This game requires  a bit of heavy specs to play on if you want to fully take in the experience more smoothly. Overall, for a steam early access game its quite impressive to see how much content has been added and how much more will be added into the future.

TLDR: 8.8 out ten.  its a great game but it is a bit of buggy and demands more Mid- high range  PCs to run.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game has the potential to be one of the best, most memorable sci-fi simulators. Unlike most early access games, this is one perhaps truly deserving of attention and in desperate need of funds. IM is one of only a handful of other early access games that I can think of truly in development, and it shows. It has a few place holder items at the moment, that in due time will be replaced. And, unlike almost any other early access title, IM is funded only by your own, and my own patronage - and perhaps the only one not funded by a kickstarter. This game doesn't happen without purchased copies or, if you have an account on the IM website, through small $5 donations. If you don't have an account, but still want to support this game, perhaps without purchasing or lacking enough funds to purchase a copy, go to the Interstellar Marines website, create an account, and make donations here and there. Every little bit helps.

I tried this game, really loved the environment.

However, as it is PVP bent, it lost at least 50%, if not more, of its potential  market and audience. Sad really that the Developer, and many players, think MMO technology require forced PVP, as though the erroneous assumption of saving money is more important than having money to save...Without buyers of the game, meaning: people who love something about the game so much they'd pay for it and Developers showing respect for that by not forcing them into activities they didn't buy the game for, there is no money to be saved. That is the epicfail of Zeropoint by making the game so PVP based PVE players only see themselves as griefed after paying money. If not for a free weekend one time I probably would have bought this game and been even more ticked off about the situation, of course the Developer probably sees that as a winning tactic" to get more money
date: the money their object not developing the game nor having a quality product in the gaming industry over the long-term.\n\nIn most circles if you buy something and then it changes or is changed away from what it posed itself to be
hoursPlayed: better known as "bait and switch
voteText: and when the Developer hides behind the Early Access legal fiction AFTER taking our money, and uses this to not develop the game according to the market that has shown interest by paying money, if without intention that's incompetence and they don't deserve to succeed. However, as is usually the case, such as with Starforge, it is with intention and that's called Gross Negligence, which in many cases is tantamount to fraud legally.\n\nPoint being, if the Developer has abandoned or is not making any effort to make the game appeal to the market, thereby securing the funds by profits from sales, funds they need to develop the game further, then whatever money they want is just stealing, irrespective of whether it's Early Access or not. Buyer beware is the axiom they depend on, which, if the company is actually trying to reach and grow their market is a reasonable idea, however, when the company exercises reckless abandon and utter failure to listen to those who've played the game, fails to pay attention to the cries for the game to be more appealing, and, fails to pay attention to how many walk away because the Developer thinks they can hide behind Early Access and ignore the players, then the entire idea of Early Access fails, and is merely a ruse to steal being taken advantage of by Con-Artists. Buyer beware is not an excuse to defraud peolpe of their money.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Sharks. With. Legs.

(Early Access Review 26/07/2015 Update 20 Unity 5)

Interstellar Marines is rich in story, development story firstly.
This is a game that was originally created in the Unreal Engine at the wrong side of the economic crash.

The outcome? A bankrupt studio and no way of affording the price of the then current Unreal pricing model.

So what did they do?

Give up?

Of course not!

They just shrugged it off and started in Unity Engine.

20 updates later and here we are at the Unity 5 update.

So what is this game all about in its current state?
What will it be like when it is finished?
Will it even be finished?
Why does everyone keep talking about sharks?
Is the IM community really that awesome?

Currently the game is all about the multiplayer, the single player and the co-op and most recently it is all about hellweek.
Multiplayer is fun, difficult, tense and frantic.
Single player is unnerving, tense and atmospheric.
Co-op is fulfilling and to be honest, a worthy challenge.
Hellweek is ambitious, sometimes cruel and unique.

When finished IM will probably be the best science fiction fps and I would go as far as saying it will probably be the bar that all other sci-fi games are judged on for single player story going forward.

Not even bankruptcy can put IM down so it seems safe to say that this game will get finished.

Sharks are scary enough at the best times but these abominations have legs. Have you even considered how scary it would be to get chased down in first person by a great white sprinting at you?

Some say that the IM community is the best community by far, all I know is that a game is only as good as its community when it comes to games with multiplayer.

I've been vague on this review, but just wanted to add more and keep building on it so it's the start.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After some time playing the game and testing all its current features, Interstellar Marines is a game I cannot recommend at its current state.

Its a very clunky, floaty, heavy work in progress.

The game doesn't run that great, even with my 780ti. Runs at 60 sometimes, but drops to 30 at random locations for no reason.

The sound design is pretty great for the most part but there appears to have a lot of gitches. Such as heavy breathing loop, audio cuts, and reverb in areas/senerios where it shouldn't be.

EDIT* Sound problems are still as persistent as ever, seems that extended play will lead to that looping heavy breathing gltich.

It also lacks content and reply value.

There are plenty of maps to play in, but lack of good enough AI and or gunplay to keep it exciting.

AI spot you across the map in dark sections of the map no problem and headshot you. AI run into walls, get caught on each other, glitch through stars.

This game at its current state is not worth the buy. It carries nothing worth while or different from any modern first person shooter.

Your better off playing Blacklight: Retribution, its essentially the same game just with far more content and its free 2 play (thought pay 2 win.)
voteText: 38 of 72 people (53%) found this review helpful 4 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Guns:
currently there are 2 guns to use: SMG and AR. the SMG has a lager magazine and is good for small-medium combat, while the AR is good for medium-long range. the combat and maps vary through the game, forcing players to use both weapons to get the most out of the game.

Maps and Game modes:
In multiplayer there is 4 game modes: deathmatch, team deathmatch, deadlock (deathmatch with capture points), and domination (one big capture point on the map). and there are 8 maps that work with all of these. the map types vary in size and location, and each game mode is fun in its own regard. there is 6 different co-op maps and a range of difficulties which drastically change the co-op gameplay.

Player base:
The game has a very small player base when compared to other gaming communities, this is both good and bad. there are less trolls in IM and active servers with experienced players can be fun, meanwhile alot of the time there might only be one active server. usually EU and US east are more active then the AU servers, leading to people always having a ping advantage, but there is server rollback to try and make this more fair, but it is always better on a closer server, like any game.

Overall:
interstellar marines is a fun, but sometimes seems repetitive (mainly co-op), it has enough content to back up the $20 price tag, and has alot of potential for a game that is still pre-alpha.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been following this game since 2009.... what can I say, the dev team is inspirational and their commitment to telling a story through game is amazing.
ATM the game consists only of a variety of multiplayer and co-op features that serve the role of providing a living platform for the team to develop around.
Even though these game modes may seem seperate from the final goal they actually fold in amazingly well with the narrative providing almost a pre-prologue setting as you train" (play the game) for the interstellar marines.

Pros:
- Amazing goals and story to be told.
- Wonderfully executed deep understanding of what makes a game immersive and captivating.
- Enjoyable early access/beta game modes.

Cons:
- Buying into this early access is a long term investment that requires a lot of trust in the dev team.
- Unless you are commited and interesting in the long term journey of this game the current material
may seem pointless/repetative/boring after a few hours play due to the slowly developing features etc.
- Due to this nature there aren't a lot of players online at any one time which limits server choice.

Do I recomend you jump on this? HELL YES!!!
But please don't expect some full stand-alone game.
This is about joining a story.... the end goal for us all is the narrative to come (just ask the devs... they wont bite)"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is the best twenty dollars I ever spent. I cannot wait to see what they plan to add to this!

THE GOOD:
I really enjoy the fast paced gunfights and the slow, nerve-racking calm before them, as you sneak around killer robots in the Neurogen Incident, or just try to get the jump on another player in the versus modes.
The multiplayer shines even with only 2 guns, each balanced for their roles perfectly, in my opinion.
I have fun with the games singleplayer/CO-OP missions, even if there is only two, because the layout offers a few ways to go about each objective.
To add to all this, the game is very immersive, all these small features that just add to the overall game very well such as: Exhaustion affecting aim, No automatic reloads, the ability to remove your visor when the helmet systems die, and even the way breath and rain can appear on your visor.

THE BAD:
I do have an issue with fps lag however, from all the dynamic lights and reflections and so forth, but its not impacting enough to detract from my enjoyment of the game.
I do wish there was more enemies to fight than just a gun robot, and a crazy melee bot.

Overall one of the best games I have played.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nInterstellar Marines is an intriguing FPS with a lot of potential. But as of now, there is only one game mode (team deathmatch), no single player campaign, and it takes forever to connect to one of the few available servers. Plus, the multiplayer is pretty bland and unbalanced. As of now, I don't think that Interstellar Marines is worth it. However, I think that you should buy this game now (the price goes up with every update) and just wait for it to be completed. If this game ends up being even half as good as it's supposed to turn out, it could easily become the best FPS on PC.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game was really rocky when it first came out, but it's far improved. Simply Preambulating the strange but really cool scifi environments is a pleasure. The game seems heavily based on knowing your surroundings and being quiet and stealthy. Some of the maps are nearly pitched black and you could 5 feet away from the enemy and they would have no idea your there. But its on you, cuz your the one whos being careful. You can hide in bushes and be near invisible. This doesnt make anything overpowering to other players as you would see if youve played it. All of the maps (the ones I've played) have an element that changes the whole map. In Elevation, different sections of the map will ascend or descend. On Evacuation, the map has weather elements that go from sneaking in the middle of the night, to being careful with every step you take on a clear afternoon. I cant say Ive necessarily played a game with the same feel as this. It's still in Beta, but as long as the team keeps working on this; It already has a lot of potential.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is still in production and it has quite a ways to go yet (I miss being able to crouch!), but so far it's looking pretty sweet. Currently the only weapon available is an assault rifle, and you have access to a laser sight and flashlight to help you see what you're aiming at. I've still no idea what benefits there are to having your visor up (or down) but it'll be interesting to see how they implement it.

The map I just played was Team Deathmatch, and the level design was like a big indoor warehouse with side corridors and huge crates stacked up everywhere. The lighting was dim, but not bad enough that I needed to use the flashlight.
We played for a while and... the lights started coming on. Dark alcoves became poor places to hide, and suddenly I was able to spot people by their shadows as they passed lighting.
A while later, the lighting shifted again as alerts went off and red lights flashed about. Hearing footsteps was more difficult and watching shadows was near-impossible.
And then... darkness. The luminescent bars on the edges of walls and on the crates made it possible to move about, but suddenly the match became a round of Marco Polo as we turned on our flashlights to check out an area and turned them off just as quickly so we wouldn't be spotted. That was exceptionally FUN, and I'd love to play that level again. :-D
It's amazing what the difference of a little bit of lighting can do to a game.

This game is far from finished, but it has a lot of potential. If you get the chance, give this a go.

Some of the maps are nearly pitched black and you could 5 feet away from the enemy and they would have no idea your there. But its on you, cuz your the one whos being careful. You can hide in bushes and be near invisible. This doesnt make anything overpowering to other players as you would see if youve played it. All of the maps (the ones I've played) have an element that changes the whole map. In Elevation, different sections of the map will ascend or descend. On Evacuation, the map has weather elements that go from sneaking in the middle of the night, to being careful with every step you take on a clear afternoon. I cant say Ive necessarily played a game with the same feel as this. It's still in Beta, but as long as the team keeps working on this; It already has a lot of potential.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After 2 hours of playing this game, I enjoyed it. It is a first person shooter in which you have to use your environment to your advantage, cooperate and eleminate your ennemies. It's gameplay style is very similar to America's army, if you think about it.

You have four options when starting the game:
Single player
Co-op
Multiplayer
Playground
They are all fun, and each add some variety . (In Co-op, you fight bots, literally)

Pros:
As of right now, there are not many good things; as in there is nothing spectacular.
-Environment interactions
-Graphics look good (like the helmet visor)
-Great maps
-You shoot people

Cons:
Interstellar marines is currently in early access, so I can forgive it's faults, but here are a couple.
-Only 2 weapons (rifle and assault rifle)
-Running only works when going straight.
-Only quality specs to lower are for the shadows
-When incapacitated, there is no way to know if you are being healed or what.
-Recoil a bit too high

These are pretty minor and will probably be fixed.

Overall, it's an enjoyable game. Unless if you are willing to play something with not much variety, I say wait out. I have high hopes for the finished product and I hope it becomes something spectacular.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Interstellar Marines IS what Skill Based FPS should be. No random spray and pray or full burst of entire magazines like in Buggerfield or Call of Copypaste, where even blind noobs can frag.

If you can't control recoil and know how to shoot / aim, you will never frag anyone even at 1m of distance.

Netcode and Hitboxes are great, 1 shot 1 kill if you go for the headshot, damage similar to other games like Insurgency or Red Orchestra.

Dynamics maps ( with fog, pitch black, sun, rain, emergency alarms only and much more weather stuff ) , stealth and tactical gameplay, no crosshair, minimal Hud with the essential you need, Marines Suits that can let you without sound or hud / no team mates indicator if you get hit harder in critical points, co-op and single player and more to come !

This game is Higly reccomended to Hardcore gamers / players that love those kind of games, casuals can use the exit door right there and go back to cod or other sellout crap games with bad netcode, balances and stuff.

You can ♥♥♥♥ in your pants too when Pitch Black turns in !

Would ♥♥♥♥ in my pants again !

10 / 10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When looking to buy this game, you should take note of the fact that it is in Early Access. This means that the playable content is very limited. However, there are 2 large co-op missions, 5 smaller co-op missions, 8 player versus player maps (I think), 2 weapons (customization is going to be added in later on for weaponry), five movement speeds (crouching, walking, crouch-running, jogging, sprinting)... it is already incredibly advanced for a game in Early Access, and the developers play the game as well, to communicate with the community and see what they want, and have excellent presence on the forums.
There are some glitches in the game. Naturally; it's Early Access. However, there are so few compared to most Early Access games, or even FPS games in general, that it's almost mind-boggling. Each update is extensively tested and prepared before it becomes available to a small segment of the community - Spearhead testers - and are then further scanned for glitches and bugs before being made available to the entire community.
Many people had a bad experience during the Free Week, and gave this game bad reviews. Unfortunately, this is mostly because of people playing it on the Free Week only to annoy other players, and the limited customization available at this point. However, what many people don't seem to understand is that it is in Early Access, even though it entered Free Week; it's nowhere near complete, and rating it as if it were the full game is unfair to the developers and potential buyers.
Now on to gameplay.
When I first began playing the game, I went into multiplayer. DO NOT DO THIS. The game is so extraordinarily fast-paced that unless you play co-op and single player first, the people in PvP will be killing you so fast you'll suspect they're hacking - quick hint, they're not; they've generally played the game for literally days straight, and have become fifty times as good as any beginner. Don't think you can compete just because you've played other FPS games.
The robots in single player and co-op are still a tremendous challenge. Start off Easy and find that, without other people to revive you, you're dead in minutes. Two to five shots will kill you in Easy, and it only gets harder.
One thing I've found is that many people complain that Realistic isn't any harder than the other modes. Here's the thing: It is, but not for the reasons most people think. Yes, the robots one-shot you on Realistic. Yes, they have a shorter delay to begin attacking once they see you. Yes, they see you better in good lighting and notice you more quickly in bad lighting. However, the real thing that got me was that the closer you are, the faster they react; open a door and there's a robot immediately on the other side? You're dead.
In spite of this game being in Early Access, the amount of content already implemented is amazing, and the gameplay and realism of the game is incredible. So there are a few glitches and fewer weapons than you'd want in an FPS game. So what? It's still remarkably complete for something in this stage.
I would definitely recommend buying this game, and if you don't feel like it's right for you, check back in a month or two; the content increases with updates constantly. The results might surprise you.

What's good:
It's a fun coop experience, it feels really unique and it requires you to think before you act whenever possible. It seems pretty realistic too (as far as that's doable in a SciFi setting), but without being annoying about it. It's great to wander around in pitch-black darkness and the adrenaline rush when something pops up right next to or behind you is something you don't find in many games these days. I didn't try much PvP" yet

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I sadly have to agree with most of the reviews.  The game has been in Early Access for years and there has been little to no development in the single and coop game modes.  All it has been is barely focusing on the multiplayer which no one plays.

The visuals are great but aren't optimized. Servers are dead. Massive lack in content.  Been in early access for years.

The devs have a lot of great ideas yet have not implemented any of the features they promised.  I would not recommend supporting this game until the devs follow up.  After years of waiting, I can safely and sadly say that I have lost hope for this promising project.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nInterstellar Marines is by far the most fun I have ever had in any game. Fight robots with your friends or go lone wolf. As of now there are few maps and guns, but despite that I find myself replaying the same map over and over again. This game allows you to use the environment and lighting to your advantage, and with the suppressors the game can be attempted from a stealth perspective. If you find yourself bored fighting with CTR's then go for some PvP. The developers are very active in the community and are concerned with your concerns. I will say that this game could be better optimized, so for those with low system specs, I would recomend waiting until it is released. FOR THE LOVE OF THE GAME!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nA very dedicated team that's heavily involved with the community. They have been posting updates regularly and keeping us informed. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Keep in mind one thing before buying this game: This game is in Alpha. Ergo, it's not a finished product.

Time of writing this review: 30/03/2014 03:10 AM (+0:00 GMT)

I've been meaning to do this review for a while but now I felt I should do it now. Too save you from reading a giant essay on why I love this game. I love everything about it. The community is one of the nicest ones I've encountered, sure, there's teamkillers, but the community notifies one another about a teamkiller if he's ingame with them. The staff team (I've only encountered one and from my experience and the experiences from a few others) are extremely friendly and nice.

This game ran on my PC which has a 3.7 GHz Quad Core AMD A10-6700 and 620 GT surprisingly well. Sure, I got 17-20 FPS, but I have to take in account that the game is in alpha, and more optimizations are to be made before the release of the finished product or the release of the beta.

The gameplay itself is quite fun, a little slow paced but nothing too slow. You will encounter different dynamic enviroment changes and enviroments. There is rain which can affect your visibility by wettening the visor on your helmet. There's night time which makes you choose between sight and stealth and a few others. The game has a cover system as of Update 10 which is actually better than most game's cover systems in my unprofessional opinion. The gun's recoil is a bit.. much and can be a little frustrating when using the sight to aim down but you really have to fire in burst shots to get the most.

This game is quite bug free and glitch free, in my entire month of owning the game, I've only encountered one bug. Which was a wall not being solid and letting the player walk through, could be abused if the wrong people find the bug. (Told the staff member I encountered about it)

Tactics isn't really teambased as there's a lack of teamchat unless you're using Steam Chat and that's really it.

A little side note: You will be seeing a load of players again and again. It's fun seeing players again and knowing how good they are.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has great tactical fps gameplay. Clever usage of the silencers and the flashlight is a must. Though in early access, the game still feels pretty complete, packing in some replayable single player missions, co-op, and a unique multiplayer experience. The environments are well done, and change often, forcing you to adapt in order to survive. The Colony map even changes shape in between and during rounds, Maze Runner style. More awesomness is sure to come with future updates. If you like tactical fps games, I highly recommend this one.

P.S. The game can be quite challenging in pvp or on higher difficulties. Be prepared for a licking until you get the hang of things.

What you get so far when buying the Early Access version:

- A single multiplayer mode, Domination"
date: with multiple servers for several regions available. 5vs5 and 8vs8 is available so far.\n- "Playgrounds": You can walk around the included multiplayer maps in Singleplayer. There is no goal
recommended: you are basically freeroaming the maps so you can learn their layouts without any stress.\n- Some tech maps for demonstration.\n- A single weapon with unlimited ammo (30 rounds/clip

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is the reason why I don't like the Idea of early access.

The whole point of Early access is so that you can support the game you want while its in development.  When in development the goal is usually to make a rough wireframe of the game.  As everyone knows, you can't edit and refine what doesn't exist.  However, this team doesn't know this.  They seem to want to appease players with small updates so that they can forever have a stream of money, with no effort involved.

When painting a picture, a scketch is drawn out first.  When making a road a path is cleared before concrete is poured.  When constructing a house a frame is built before the walls.  Games are suppose to be made in a similar fashion.

The game that was promised years ago will at this snails pace take decades to complete.

By then it will have been forgotten, and nobody will miss it.
voteText: 8 of 14 people (57%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Reviewed after update 23

Gameplay: 300+ hours

Cool game mechanics:
-Realistic gun recoil
-Exhausted?  You will find it harder to aim, your heavy breathing will make it harder to hear also.
-Hearing is just as important as seeing.
-Minimal hud but still full of tons of information, however it deactivates when your suit is damaged.
-That light giving away your position in the dark?  Try shooting it out
-React to conditions and accept consequences dynamically.  Silent enviroment? Players/bots will hear you running.  Dark Enviroment?  Players/bots will see your flashlight.

Solo/Coop:
-Solid AI, very well done.  Have fun tricking robots into looking behind boxes that they thought you ran behind.  Have fun getting mad when they see your muzzle flash/flashlight from across the map (just like you can).  They have similar restrictions as the player including health.  A fun challange to play on realistic.
-Good assistance and teamwork mechanics.  Its easy to feel hindered when you have a bad team, in fact it is usually easier to play alone than with a bad team.  However with a good team you can cut through maps like melted butter.  Things like needing a teammate to watch your back or cover you while you reload actually can be quite benificial.
-Level design and attention to detail.  Some of the best installation designs I've seen in a game.  Can be a bit overwhelming at first, just like if you walked into a real military research base or commercial space station.
-Only a few weapons but they are well done and feel right.  Feels like a soldier getting a standard loadout.

Multiplayer:
-A dynamic training enviroment where the enviroment can wildly change from brightly lit to hurricane condtions to pitch black.  Very fun and totally changes the way the match is playing.
-Want to run and gun?  That is okay but deal with the exhaustion and inability to aim well.  Want to run around with a laser sight (which acts as a crosshair) then be ready to give away your position.  There is no wrong answer to tactics, just results.


tl;dr:

This game is fun and enjoyable.  Get to watch a single person take out a whole team using stealth in the dark.  Watch people complain that stealth has no purpose.

11/10 would play again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Here's the conversation me and my friend had after playing a couple of games of IM:

Dansrage: whats the point of this I can just play Insurgency lol
Arthur Von Winklehammer: Right dude?
Dansrage: let's go play play Insurgency
Arthur Von Winklehammer: aha alright

Visually this game is quite impressive, excluding the endlessly copy/paste assets and environments, the lighting is nice, the weapon models are good, the rain on your visor is reminiscent of Metroid Prime, but there's just nothing under the hood.

There are three game modes in IM, Campaign, Coop and Multiplayer.
In campaign and coop you'll play on the exact same maps, with the exact same bots. There are minor variations of gametype that essentially boil down to kill all the guys" or "press all the buttons while you kill the guys".
This isn't bad in itself if the gameplay is engaging
date: but unfortunately it isn't. Bot AI will either run directly into your bullets or stand still and fire at you. The atmosphere with it's excellent sound design and moody lighting is obviously aiming for creepy

reviewText:
Early Access Review

IMPORTANT NOTE: This is only for the Early Access content as of August 2014. My rating is subject to change once more is added.


The Review: ISM is very lite on content, to me. It has a couple multiplayer competitive maps, and a early demo for Co-op mode where you and a friend kill robots while trying to reach the roof. 2 guns, no grenades or customization or any other weapons, not even melee. The 2 guns are both Assault Rifles with emphasis on different engagement ranges.

I see the potential for an amazing game, but right now it's just too simple. The lighting adds a good layer to the game, as well as the decision to use a laser and give away your position in return for better hip aiming. It seems you can take off your helmet but this currently seems to have no effect other than removing the hud; I assume this will result in your suit powering down (no lights) eventually, but it's not the case currently.

In summary: If you are you are interested in their concept, get this on sale maybe. I got it in a Humble Bundle and don't regret it. But if you want a good game to sink hours into, I don't see it happening here, yet. Keep an eye on ISM though, I do expect it to become awesome eventually.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EDIT: I did a bit of research after writing this and found that the game was actually announced *11* (ELEVEN) years ago.  That's right, this game has been around for over a decade and there still is nothing to show for it.  The most recent update as of May 21st 2016, rather than adding anything meaningful, added a new Main Menu UI and weapon skins, and the option to vote on what map you would like to play when your current round is over.  Two months for weapon skins and a new main menu.  Sorry folks but I don't think that asking for something other than that is very unreasonable at this point.  Please don't drop money on this until the devs have some actual, functionable content ready.

I read a preview for the game I want to say around 6-7 years ago in the back of a magazine at the library.  It detailed what the developers wanted to do and how they wanted to do it.  Fast forward 6-7 years and so far we have a slightly above average multiplayer TDM/Domination game put together in Unity.  It's above average because they've obviously spent quite a bit of time and money putting the game together, there are some neat ideas in regard to how guns handle and how you move.  The sound design in particular is very well done, especially noting the differences when you play with your helmet on or off.  I purchased the Spearhead Edition for $45 on their website back in 2010 when I was back in college, back when the game was only playable in your browser and was only a few sets of target practice modes.  If the game had been released shortly after, even 2-3 years later, then it would have been fine.  However, that is simply not the case for Interstellar Marines.

The bad parts are, like I mentioned earlier, that this game has been in development hell for what will be coming up on a decade now.  There has been numerous issues, engine changes, failed crowdfunding attempts, accidental" key giveaways that gave people who purchased the game all of the special legacy upgrades that people who paid $40+ five years ago originally had (Spearhead Edition benefits).  They say the concept is to have an "indie-AAA" where the production values are AAA while being "published by the community."  This is absolutely fine
date: and it's worked for many other developers and games.\n\nThis title
hoursPlayed: has been in development for *years* and the only progress that has been made is adding a relatively uninteresting multiplayer component (You would be *very* lucky to find more than a dozen or so people playing
voteText: even on their "Hell Weeks") and a few uninspired singleplayer missions that revolve around you shooting robots

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game certainly has potential, but the same can be said about a lot of titles that have not delivered what was promised.  While graphically pleasing, the game currently lacks what I consider to be any decent gameplay.  Multiplayer death matches are pretty much all you have to look forward to if you buy this game which is *not* worth the money in my opinion.  With these things in mind I will point out the pros and cons of this game as best as I see them.

Pros:

(The graphics are more than I expected and makes the game look quite believeable.
(Weapon performance is surprsingly good, with the sounds and recoil reminding me of actual rifles I have fired.
(The heads up display mixed with the toggle modes on the helmet makes me feel like my head is actually in the helmet, which reminds me somewhat of the metro series.  This is a great immersion modifier.
(The dynamic weather system the have in the arena is very well done and they demonstrate that they can develope immersive environments within their game.

Cons:

(While the devs have multiple gamemodes"
date: all of them occur within an enclosed arena which
hoursPlayed: gets dull really fast.  Again
voteText:
the lack of gameplay variety just ruins this for me.
(Next to no visible progress on this game.  I understand the time it takes to develope such things but their updates  are both irregular and sparse.  I see no indication that this game is going anywhere fast.
(Lack of player customization leaves me feeling like a stormtrooper with no identity.  This breaks the immersion greatly in my mind.

Overall I'd say that this game has the barebones framework that can be the foundation of something awesome

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's incredible on how this game is so realistic, yet still in it's developing stages. There are multiple maps with envorinment settings. So you can go to one server with a map and it's raining, and as you play in the map the weather actually changes to where it'll be easier to fight, or to where it'll be harder to fight.

-Weaponry/Equipment: At this time, there is only 1 weapon, which is an assault rifle. Yet, you also have the abiloity to activate a lazer for you to help with your accurasy, a flashlight incase it get's dark (game sometimes has you in pitch black darkness), of course you can zoom in by right-clicking, and unlike any sci-fi FPS, you can actually take off your visor. So it'll be like fighting with literally your own eyes. But the game doesn't give you a cursor to aim with like Halo, Battlefield, TF2, etc. You actually have to aim like everyone does in real life when in combat.

-Maps: There are multiple maps that go from the middle of a swamp, to the cold regions, to a colony in the forest. All maps has the ability to change the weather to throw off players.

-Game Mode: So far, there is only one game mode where you hold a certain area for the longest, but as time goes on, the capture zone will move into a different area of the map. In order to win, you must hold the capture zone for the longest when the time runs out, or when the amount of time you hold it reaches it's max. Either way, you have to work with your team in order to win. Cooperation and skill will bring you to victory in this game.

Overall, this game is incredible for it to be an Early Access Game, I recommend this game to anyone that reads this.

this game is really good
overall My opinion:8/10 highly recomend

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Interstellar Marines. What can I say? Well, for one, CoD fans REALLY missed out on this one. Second, this review:

Interstellar Marines is a sci-fi FPS that has AMAZING potential. I could see this being a revolutionary game in the near future. The devs are very involved with the community, it has a basic attatchment system, and the Co-op robots never seem to stop FREAKING ME THE HELL OUTOHMYGODPLEASEDONTKILLME!
But, in all seriousness, this game is a very solid, immersive game, with the only thing that could add to the immersion is Oculus support. The Winter Holidays event is DM with the T-IM101: A christmas-light-filled, yelling, insanely stat-boosted Arnold Shwarzeneggar inside a spacesuit that possesses you when you touch a present. Yeah.

The updates also never fail to bring new and interesting content, and you will be on the edge of your seat waiting for the next addition by Zero Pont Software.
There aren't many weapons, but after you have the basic weapons (Assault Rifle, Pistol, SMG, Sniper Rifle, maybe a Grenade Launcher as a special pickup, etc.), they should focus on customization & attachments (If they aren't doing that already). The few weapons only adds to the balance and tactical-ness of the game.

However, no system is without its... Kinks. Phone Guy said that, and it is very true, especially with Early Access games. The updates DO take a while to come out, so you'll be on the edge of your seat for a while. There is, however, no issue with crashing or glitching as far as I'm concerned.

So, TL;DR, a very solid and immersive game with tight shooting, superb graphics, and updates and robots that never fail to impress and scare. Respectively.
10/10

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nInterstellar Marines is a fantastic sci-fi 1st person shooter. The developers show that they care by using tons of detail. The enviornments change, from day to night to rain to snow in just a short match. The player has so many decisions to make when this fantastic enviornment changes, you can use a flashlight attachment to your gun, have a laser sight, open and close your helmet visor. For example, in the night you can choose to use your flashlight to find people or you can creep around in the shadows (in the dark.) Another nice feature is you can walk around the maps by yourself and get to them before challenging others. This game is early access so you can imagine there are a few turn-off's as of right now, lag, the campaign has not been added yet, and sadly as far as I know there is only 1 or 2 guns in multiplayer. Overall though I would recommend it, if you are intrested I would purchase this game asap before it becomes to expensive because I think this game has a great future. It is a blast in my opinion similar to Halo and Call of Duty mixed with an amazing fighting enviornment. I would ABSOLUTELY recomend this game to anyone who likes 1st person shooter games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's incredible on how this game is so realistic, yet still in it's developing stages. There are multiple maps with envorinment settings. So you can go to one server with a map and it's raining, and as you play in the map the weather actually changes to where it'll be easier to fight, or to where it'll be harder to fight.

-Weaponry/Equipment: At this time, there is only 1 weapon, which is an assault rifle. Yet, you also have the abiloity to activate a lazer for you to help with your accurasy, a flashlight incase it get's dark (game sometimes has you in pitch black darkness), of course you can zoom in by right-clicking, and unlike any sci-fi FPS, you can actually take off your visor. So it'll be like fighting with literally your own eyes. But the game doesn't give you a cursor to aim with like Halo, Battlefield, TF2, etc. You actually have to aim like everyone does in real life when in combat.

-Maps: There are multiple maps that go from the middle of a swamp, to the cold regions, to a colony in the forest. All maps has the ability to change the weather to throw off players.

-Game Mode: So far, there is only one game mode where you hold a certain area for the longest, but as time goes on, the capture zone will move into a different area of the map. In order to win, you must hold the capture zone for the longest when the time runs out, or when the amount of time you hold it reaches it's max. Either way, you have to work with your team in order to win. Cooperation and skill will bring you to victory in this game.

Overall, this game is incredible for it to be an Early Access Game, I recommend this game to anyone that reads this.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There are far more detailed reviews than my own.

This game however is honestly splendid.
Personally i use it at the moment for a quick shoot 'em up match now and then, i purchased it in anticipation for the long awaited campaign mode. The reason i use this for a quick match type of game is purely because of the launch speed, and i'm on Mac for god's sake. So if you happen to be 'one of those people' that just cannot wait five seconds for a game to boot, you're covered with Interstellar Marines (i imagine when the ever growing content is updated to include campaign mode the start time won't be as brisk).

Furthermore, the detail and as the developers have worked for; immersion, is superior. I have experienced no bugs what so ever and not once have i lagged during gameplay which has been excellent.

Yes, the game is no where near completed. Alas i like to think of this as a good thing. You can be sure your purchase was not in vain as future content is assured.
The sort of things to come are displayed on various Zeropoint websites including some pretty nifty videos (including the campaign 'Landsharks') and a few demonstration games to play with.

Summed up, Interstellar Marines was well worth the low price despite the Early Access title.
Purchasing the game now helps the developers create the final product, there's little to lose.

My only, only issue- in the entire game would be the reeds on one of the levels. Upon close inspection they appear to be rather pixilated. Though by saying that i am REALLY nit-picking, everything else is flawless including the rather uniquely atmospheric lighting system.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The state it's currently in, there's not much to experience in Interstellar Marines. I've only played multiplayer, however. You are given two guns, one for close to mid-range combat, another for mid to long-range. Both guns can have silencers, flashlights, and laser sights toggled.

There aren't that many maps yet, which is super understandable, but the maps that are provided are extremely balanced. Maybe too balanced for some, but balanced nonetheless. The maps also change over the course of each round, which is extremely interesting. Platforms move up and down, rain starts to fall (muffling the sound of your footsteps), and the lighting changes. One of my favorite things about this is when the lights go out. Fighting in the dark is insanely satisfying. You never really know what's going on... but in a good way.

There's a quite a few bugs here and there, but it's in alpha. Of course there's bugs. This game has a hell of a lot of potential; it looks like it could become the FPS I've been waiting for.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have only played the single player so far but from what i have played i am really liking this game. the main things that make this game fun for me  are:
1. there is no mini map to show where the bad guys are
2. there are no checkpoints so if you die , you start over on the mission
3. i feel the aiming and handling of the weapons is super smooth and just feels really good
4. these 3 things together make for a slow paced, very tactical shooter where you must move slow and constantly check the environment around you to not end up dead and back at the start.
5. terminator robots, who don't like those?
6. realistic mode is very challenging seeing as you will die from one hit from the robots, but very satisfying when your able to pick off the enemies and progress.
7. the dark creepy environment where its best to leave the fllashlight off and only use it briefly to get a quick view of your surroundings. to me it keeps me on edge and my heart pounding.
8. the devs are in the forums answering questions and making sure they stay civil and trying to keep the trolls and flamers out
in conclusion i say give this game a shot it's free for the week so you have nothing to lose especially as it's only 1gb to download so like 2minutes of your time. i's not gonna be for everyone but if you like tactical games where you don't just run around like some movie hero who can't be hurt it might be for you. I'll add more once  i have tried co-op and mp. plus i know for $6 i will get my monies worth even if it takes the devs a while to finish it.

edit: im thinking checkpoints on the easiest difficulty might be nice just so you can figure out how to complete a mission without dying after 2hrs not knowing if you were close to the escape or in the entirely wrong spot, but i hear they might be coming

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Interstellar Marines by Zero Point Software, seems like a fairly nice game for the STEAM Early Access price starting at under $18.99.  It has a single-player mode, but more importantly a four-player coop mode is already present.  The shining uniqueness about the game is that it is 90% community funded and 95% community driven... it also it has space sharks?

Over time the developers are releasing small pieces of the game that focus on specific systems - shooting, movement, settings, actual content, etc.  Zero Point is made up of two developers who are independant of the big publishing companies and mainstream support.  So updates and added content is a very, very, very slow process.  This could be a potential problem for some gamers and a deal-breaking-con for others.

Zero Point have put out a video showcasing new footage of the game and bringing you up to speed on its development.  Right now you can sign up for a free account at the game's official website and play any of the pieces right in your web browser!

==> http://www.interstellarmarines.com/

The technology is pretty impressive, the game looks great, and there's even achievements and leaderboards to track your progress if you are into that sort of thing.

Game Machanics:  The fluid first person view is kind of flexible.  You an run, walk fast, and jump a little.

Weapons and Gear: There's only a rifle and SMG.  Both have reflex style sights with an optional laser dot.  You get a flashlight for those darkend areas of the game.

[center][flash(425,350)]http://www.youtube.com/v/dhk-2Wb_IyQ[/flash][/center]

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFrom what I played, this game is goregeous. It doesn't really rely on online multiplayer team vs. team combat like most FPS nowadays. You can play singleplayer missions, co-op with a few friends, and if you really want to, you can play multiplayer. Visually, it's stunning. The effects on the visor are new to sci-fi shooters and really haven't seen that done before. I didn't get my chance to try out multiplayer against other players quite yet, and don't think I'll get the chance for a while. Although this game is fantastic, and is different from the many shooters that it's in the market against, it lacks one thing that might make this better for us, not so rich people that can't afford to buy a gaming pc. A graphics tab. It does have the v-sync, etc. stuff, but I maybe want to lower some of the quality to medium instead of always being on high. For laptop users, like myself, this is a big issue that we have to deal with. I'm not saying my laptop is terrible graphically or anything, but a graphics tab, visual quality slider could be useful to many players. Other than that, this game is fantasic and hell yeah I recommend it to a friend!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been following this game, for a few years; basically I seen mutant land sharks, and well I am still left waiting for it.

Lets be honest this game is early access but its good, the basics are there, and the shooting omg, I havent played a game that I feel like Im actually hitting where I aim. Perhaps many will say its unrealistic as there doest seem to have any variation of flight, but damn it feels good to know you as the player are on point.

Where is the game now? Well, its playable with a some bugs that are easily repeatable but nothing that breaks the game. There are 7 maps, and really it doesnt seem like much. And once you clear them all with you group of friends its hard to go back to them. And you will need friends, this game can be hard and failing is a part of it, but with a full group of friends there are alot of tactics to try in all the maps  in all the modes. It just feels like there isnt enough game yet, esp with updates so far between eachother. The online server chooser needs to be fleshed out a bit, currently a slight pain to get a game going, but not hard either, just missing some nicities.

So for me and my group, there isnt enough yet for us to buy into I.M.'s Early Access yet. BUT if an update adds the sharks and give me some LAN play, I'm all in. It just need a bit more.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There are far more detailed reviews than my own.

This game however is honestly splendid.
Personally i use it at the moment for a quick shoot 'em up match now and then, i purchased it in anticipation for the long awaited campaign mode. The reason i use this for a quick match type of game is purely because of the launch speed, and i'm on Mac for god's sake. So if you happen to be 'one of those people' that just cannot wait five seconds for a game to boot, you're covered with Interstellar Marines (i imagine when the ever growing content is updated to include campaign mode the start time won't be as brisk).

Furthermore, the detail and as the developers have worked for; immersion, is superior. I have experienced no bugs what so ever and not once have i lagged during gameplay which has been excellent.

Yes, the game is no where near completed. Alas i like to think of this as a good thing. You can be sure your purchase was not in vain as future content is assured.
The sort of things to come are displayed on various Zeropoint websites including some pretty nifty videos (including the campaign 'Landsharks') and a few demonstration games to play with.

Summed up, Interstellar Marines was well worth the low price despite the Early Access title.
Purchasing the game now helps the developers create the final product, there's little to lose.

My only, only issue- in the entire game would be the reeds on one of the levels. Upon close inspection they appear to be rather pixilated. Though by saying that i am REALLY nit-picking, everything else is flawless including the rather uniquely atmospheric lighting system.
