reviewText:
Early Access Review

In its current state it is a very good game. The only thing that bothers me is its unoptimized state in which it is, but since it is in early access I'll let it slide for now.

Singleplayer:

Before I installed the game I read reviews about it and saw that people got scared while playing singleplayer.
At first I was confused as to how a shooter with robots can be scary. Then I played the singleplayer and I understood.
It's pretty scary when a robot starts to run towards you. Although they may seem non-frightening, their faceless head can spook you once it randomly pops up in front of you.

Co-op:
Didn't play so I can't comment on that, sorry.

Multiplayer:
The multiplayer for Interstellar Marines was quite fun for me actually, although in my past I played only CoD multiplayer(long time ago). To be honest it took me a little to get used to the guns(only 2 for now) and the lack of crosshair(instead you use a laser), but because of this I was forced to focus on my little tiny dot and I was sucked into the game. The game for now has a small amount of maps, but the ones that are in it currently are very well designed and I look forward to future maps. The players that I played with didn't chat alot so but the ones that did were very nice.

I would recommend this game to the people who love strategic shoters as it involves alot of tactical cooperation between players, if you want to win ofcourse.

Although I played the game while it was free for a couple of days, I will buy it as soon as I get money as it is worth the money and the wait for better optimization.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The state it's currently in, there's not much to experience in Interstellar Marines. I've only played multiplayer, however. You are given two guns, one for close to mid-range combat, another for mid to long-range. Both guns can have silencers, flashlights, and laser sights toggled.

There aren't that many maps yet, which is super understandable, but the maps that are provided are extremely balanced. Maybe too balanced for some, but balanced nonetheless. The maps also change over the course of each round, which is extremely interesting. Platforms move up and down, rain starts to fall (muffling the sound of your footsteps), and the lighting changes. One of my favorite things about this is when the lights go out. Fighting in the dark is insanely satisfying. You never really know what's going on... but in a good way.

There's a quite a few bugs here and there, but it's in alpha. Of course there's bugs. This game has a hell of a lot of potential; it looks like it could become the FPS I've been waiting for.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have only played the single player so far but from what i have played i am really liking this game. the main things that make this game fun for me  are:
1. there is no mini map to show where the bad guys are
2. there are no checkpoints so if you die , you start over on the mission
3. i feel the aiming and handling of the weapons is super smooth and just feels really good
4. these 3 things together make for a slow paced, very tactical shooter where you must move slow and constantly check the environment around you to not end up dead and back at the start.
5. terminator robots, who don't like those?
6. realistic mode is very challenging seeing as you will die from one hit from the robots, but very satisfying when your able to pick off the enemies and progress.
7. the dark creepy environment where its best to leave the fllashlight off and only use it briefly to get a quick view of your surroundings. to me it keeps me on edge and my heart pounding.
8. the devs are in the forums answering questions and making sure they stay civil and trying to keep the trolls and flamers out
in conclusion i say give this game a shot it's free for the week so you have nothing to lose especially as it's only 1gb to download so like 2minutes of your time. i's not gonna be for everyone but if you like tactical games where you don't just run around like some movie hero who can't be hurt it might be for you. I'll add more once  i have tried co-op and mp. plus i know for $6 i will get my monies worth even if it takes the devs a while to finish it.

edit: im thinking checkpoints on the easiest difficulty might be nice just so you can figure out how to complete a mission without dying after 2hrs not knowing if you were close to the escape or in the entirely wrong spot, but i hear they might be coming

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you're looking to buy Inserstellar marines as of today: December 2nd 2014

I'd recommend this in some circumstances.
The game is fun and offers a base-level immersive tactical experience while maintaining just the right level of arcade influence.
The graphics are excellent, considering the low texture fidelity, continues to prove that lighting can pretty much make or break a game as far as visual fidelity is concerned. Neurogen Incident certainly shows this off, creating a tense co op experience.
The UI can be a bit cumbersome, as I understand that it's meant to be immersive it can still prove to be a pain given the amount of time a chat message appears on screen. Thus forcing you to bring up the chat menu, I'd prefer if they showed all messages from the past 5-10 seconds and slowly faded them out based on lifetime. Making the social experience a bit less frustrating.
Something to be noted is the gunplay is not like anything I've experienced it's hard to describe really any other way than it feeling like you're controlling something and it has a considerable latency. Keep in mind my setup has no latency issues monitor is 1ms response time graphics card is more than capable... etc. Not to mention in the game's current state the community is quite small, it's hard to keep an audience's attention when you have such little content to show for, regardless of the content's magnitude.

All this taken into consideration also with the fact that this game is still early access, the game is quite unique and definitely delivers an FPS experience unlike anything else I have had. I'd certainly recommend this to a friend who was looking for a basic and immersive tactical FPS for PC.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game has some amazing potential. Despite the (current) lack of content, the dev team has already nailed the atmosphere of Dead Space cross Rainbow Six , with some surprisingly immersive gameplay and gorgeous graphics from the Unity Engine. Your player character is very human-slow, vulnerable, and brave. Teamwork is just as important as twitch reflexes and awareness of your enviroment, and while the game can be played alone it is difficult and boring without at least someone else by your side. The game currently fearures a decent Multiplayer experience, several solo challenge missions, and two epic story missions pitting you and a team of 3 others up against intelligent and dangerous training robots simulating events from the IM backstory. While many features such as more guns (currently only 2), missions, and enemies (Land Sharks), the game feels balanced and very well done. According to the devs, this has been tehir life's dream for almost 20 years now, and they are very unlikely to give up and leave this as vaporware. The one complaint I have is the development cycle: with only 12 people building the equivalent of a AAA-quality title, it takes several months to update the content. If you're willing to wait, gab the game and start playing-realistic difficulty is hard and takes a lot of cooperation and skill to complete, so don't excpet to be bored. And if it feels too risky, keep an eye on Interstella Marines-this game is going places.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

================================================================

NB: Steam's review upvote/downvote is meant to be used by mature and objective readers to indicate whether a review was helpful. Instead, many readers use it only to indicate whether they agree/disagree with the review. What that means is if a reader likes the game but dislikes a negative review of the game, they will downvote the review for that reason alone. People do this to make it harder for reviews they disagree with to appear on Steam and therefore harder for you to make an informed decision.

So a wise person will seek out both positive and negative reviews not based on upvote/downvote status.

================================================================

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been following this game, for a few years; basically I seen mutant land sharks, and well I am still left waiting for it.

Lets be honest this game is early access but its good, the basics are there, and the shooting omg, I havent played a game that I feel like Im actually hitting where I aim. Perhaps many will say its unrealistic as there doest seem to have any variation of flight, but damn it feels good to know you as the player are on point.

Where is the game now? Well, its playable with a some bugs that are easily repeatable but nothing that breaks the game. There are 7 maps, and really it doesnt seem like much. And once you clear them all with you group of friends its hard to go back to them. And you will need friends, this game can be hard and failing is a part of it, but with a full group of friends there are alot of tactics to try in all the maps  in all the modes. It just feels like there isnt enough game yet, esp with updates so far between eachother. The online server chooser needs to be fleshed out a bit, currently a slight pain to get a game going, but not hard either, just missing some nicities.

So for me and my group, there isnt enough yet for us to buy into I.M.'s Early Access yet. BUT if an update adds the sharks and give me some LAN play, I'm all in. It just need a bit more.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There are far more detailed reviews than my own.

This game however is honestly splendid.
Personally i use it at the moment for a quick shoot 'em up match now and then, i purchased it in anticipation for the long awaited campaign mode. The reason i use this for a quick match type of game is purely because of the launch speed, and i'm on Mac for god's sake. So if you happen to be 'one of those people' that just cannot wait five seconds for a game to boot, you're covered with Interstellar Marines (i imagine when the ever growing content is updated to include campaign mode the start time won't be as brisk).

Furthermore, the detail and as the developers have worked for; immersion, is superior. I have experienced no bugs what so ever and not once have i lagged during gameplay which has been excellent.

Yes, the game is no where near completed. Alas i like to think of this as a good thing. You can be sure your purchase was not in vain as future content is assured.
The sort of things to come are displayed on various Zeropoint websites including some pretty nifty videos (including the campaign 'Landsharks') and a few demonstration games to play with.

Summed up, Interstellar Marines was well worth the low price despite the Early Access title.
Purchasing the game now helps the developers create the final product, there's little to lose.

My only, only issue- in the entire game would be the reeds on one of the levels. Upon close inspection they appear to be rather pixilated. Though by saying that i am REALLY nit-picking, everything else is flawless including the rather uniquely atmospheric lighting system.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI haven't played a lot of this game, but what I did I thoroughly enjoyed. Honestly the reason I only played as little as I did was because it was a lot scarier than what I expected. I know that may sound childish but seriously, it was freaking terrifying. The single player tutorial: you're thrown into a room full of bloodthirsty androids with nothing but an SMG, an assault rifle, and whatever god you believe in. Then suddenly the lights go out, and all you can hear is the robotic hiss and footsteps of the creatures created solely to destroy you. As your heart starts rapidly beating the footsteps grow closer, you ready your gun to defend yourself... then BANG you're dead sucks you're awful at the game and now you're crying on the floor begging for your mother. That's how I felt.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In its current state it is a very good game. The only thing that bothers me is its unoptimized state in which it is, but since it is in early access I'll let it slide for now.

Singleplayer:

Before I installed the game I read reviews about it and saw that people got scared while playing singleplayer.
At first I was confused as to how a shooter with robots can be scary. Then I played the singleplayer and I understood.
It's pretty scary when a robot starts to run towards you. Although they may seem non-frightening, their faceless head can spook you once it randomly pops up in front of you.

Co-op:
Didn't play so I can't comment on that, sorry.

Multiplayer:
The multiplayer for Interstellar Marines was quite fun for me actually, although in my past I played only CoD multiplayer(long time ago). To be honest it took me a little to get used to the guns(only 2 for now) and the lack of crosshair(instead you use a laser), but because of this I was forced to focus on my little tiny dot and I was sucked into the game. The game for now has a small amount of maps, but the ones that are in it currently are very well designed and I look forward to future maps. The players that I played with didn't chat alot so but the ones that did were very nice.

I would recommend this game to the people who love strategic shoters as it involves alot of tactical cooperation between players, if you want to win ofcourse.

Although I played the game while it was free for a couple of days, I will buy it as soon as I get money as it is worth the money and the wait for better optimization.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As an Early Access game, it has managed to keep my attention ever since its initial release.

The game has come a long way since its initial release, and the updates are starting to come in faster and faster. If one wants to know how far this game has come, check out videos of the original release vs the current game version (Update 18 for the time this review was written).

In terms of gameplay, here is what players can expect to see (As of Update 18):

Solid gunplay mechanics. the weapon's sights aren't glued" to your screen
date: and will move around as you walk
hoursPlayed: etc. (Think kind of like Red Orchestra). The weapon does reset at the centre of your screen however.\n\nA stamina system that affects your character's accuracy as he gets tired. Stamina is drained when jogging
voteText: sprinting
helpfulPercent: and jumping. You can hear your character's breathing and when your HUD is offline
votesHelpful: his breath will fog up the inside of the helmet.\n\nAn intuitive crouching system that allows you to change stance between a low crouch or a higher stance to shoot over low walls. Aiming down sights will also make your character peek over cover
votesTotal: and if you change stance while aiming
votesFunny: he will only bend at the knees for faster movement.\n\nSprint
commentsCount: Jog
column16:
and walk. Three movement speeds that are very useful and easy to cycle through.

Two weapons. An Assault Rifle for long range combat and an SMG for close range combat.

The ability to attach a sound suppressor to your weapon. It actually works really well in both multiplayer and co-op/single player

You can shoot out lights to create darkness in order to sneak around (Think Metro 2033/ Last Light)

Multiplayer maps will change time of day
column17: weather
column18: and sometimes layout as you play. Matches have a sense of unpredictability for newcomers because of this.\n\nThree game modes to chose from: Deathmatch
column19: Team Deathmatch
column20: and Domination.\n\n3 campaign missions
column21: and a few other side-missions. Currently
column22:
all missions are training excercises for your character (A new recruit to the Interstellar Marines).

HUD deactivates when you take 50% damage. This makes it hard to identify between friend and foe because IFF markers and objective markers all vanish.


I hope that this review has convinced at least one person to try out the game. Despite all the praise I'm throwing at it
column23: note that there are many missing features in the game. The updates have been coming in more quickly recently
column24: and a big one is apparently going to be coming in soon. So if you feel like taking a risk and betting on this extremely promising title
column25: I highly suggest that you buy it. If you can

column27: March 2, 2015

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really want to get this review right as I REALLY want you to buy this game that is how much I recommend Interstellar Marines! Even if you buy it now and don't like it, which you would have to be crazy not to, this will be an investment. Simply because Interstellar marines is a game to watch, with a ton of future potential and that future isn't far off.

The game, as it is, puts you in the boots of a Marine undergoing training in preperation for combat missions that will take you to the furthest reaches of human expansion in the universe that will lead to first contact with other intelligent life in a very realisitc way.

The developers are fantastic, dedicated, imaginative and have in my opinion (and I know this is a review) have given to us as customers the most brilliant concept for a game I can concieve espically the way they have implemented dynamic environments.
When the lights are on you walk about like you own the place but the dark corners you still avoid, when they go out completely you hide in the corners edging along walls frightened to turn on your flash light because the dark just seems so vast because when all the lights go out it really is pitch black and the dark feels real.
The weather is also diverse with rain that falls on your visor obscuring your vision really giving you a sense of presense and depth like no other game offers.

The weapons feel like tools of war rather than cap guns, the sounds of your boots on the floor make you concentrate on moving forward, the only sound this game is missing to make you feel alive is the sound of your heart beating but then you might be able to hear it but I could not over the sound of my own.

The graphics are impressive when you can see and when you can not. If you look outide at the stars you get a sense of loneliness that not many games give you that take you to space but that might have something to do with what is waiting for you inside. The jungle like environment on one map even though it covers only one half of the map is amazing with a great sense of being in a real life jungle which at times is like being in the dark because all you see is different shades of green.

The AI is the best I have ever experienced, even when compared to arma because the AI in interstellar marines is way more intelligent they react to light, the environment and when they are fired upon. If you are standing on a catwalk and shoot down at them they will seek cover out of view, taking you by surprise when you are forced to go down and deal with them. The dev's even said they would rather have one intelligent AI than several dumb ones which should give you an even better idea of how good they are.

So ISM is simply the most dynamic, believeable and suspenseful experiences you will hopefully ever feel in a FPS all while being a beautiful game with an almost perfect community and development team!

Thumbs up with a well desevered recommendation and big thank you to Zero Point software for such a brilliant game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This isn't a reinvention of the FPS genre, but it does add some mechanics that have been controversial.

Before I outline those issues, it should be known that this is a great game at a great price.

During my playtime, some issues that I have heard random people scream about is the lack of jump or crouch.  This is a very simple FPS that is currently in ALPHA and it is a shame when new players are too selfish or ignorant to realize what an Alpha means.

If you are looking for regular FPS style mechanics, this will not be your cup of tea, but if you are interested in innovative game play, tug-o-war scoring and a good (on the most part) community, give it a try.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Interstellar Marines (Early Access) quick-review:
Pros:
- Great Lighting effects!
- Extremely good use of sound. Sound is very important when playing the game.
- Creative new game modes. (Like the last man standing/domination hybrid)
- Very cool environments that dynamically change during matches which can very quickly change the way you play the game.
- Very smooth gun-play. Aiming and shooting feels" really good.

Cons:
- Early access (There's not a lot of content at this stage
recommended:
performance on each PC may vary)
- Few servers (Likely to be fixed closer to launch)
- Few players (Just not many people playing it at the moment which is fair enough).
- A lot of features/content in the game description has not yet been added to the game.

Verdict:
If you are after a full featured game - hold of on buying until release (Or at least closer to release).
However if you want to try out one of the most unique multiplayer FPS gaming experience you've tried in a while - grab the early access copy and give it a try!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After heavy ammounts of playtime and enjoyment. I have re-done my review and decided to spend a few minutes re-writing it.

I found I.M one day looking for a game. I bought it, Played it, and enjoyed it. And I kept coming back for more. I was just a small fish in a big pond. Look at me now, after around 2 years of I.M somehow I managed to join 2 Oceanic competitive clans, won four clan compition matches, won 5-6 Hell Weeks and created the biggest and coolest unofficial game mode there is... Hide 'n Go Taze".

Co-op is solid so far and enjoyable with mates and by yourself if you want to practise. Multiplayer is so much fun if you get to know people and know what you are doing. I would reccomend making a few friends buy this game and play Multiplayer with you as it may be dead sometimes during the day.

Hell Week is a lot of fun. Better than it used to be now that CTR's and supply drops were added. Devs are good listeners and care about what they do. They actually confess if they mucked something up or did something wrong
date: which gets them respect in my book.\n\nNow after this read
recommended: hopefully I convinced you to buy this little gem. Go taze some fellow marines in the face.\n\n(The bushes are STILL bulletproof)"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you're like me, you've probably lost interest in shooters the likes of Call of Duty several years ago. Tactical shooters seem to have passed into history and games like the Rainbow Six series have no equals in today's gaming landscape. Interstellar Marines is an admirable attempt to ressurect this genre and is absolutely brimming with potential. In it's current state the game is lacking in both content and polish. There's a few weapons, a handful of maps and some single player content that feels like a tutorial. There are no real tactical options yet and simple features like peeking around a corner are lacking. Still the game is an absolute thrill to play. I found myself holding my breath while sneaking through a futuristic compound, listening for robotic footsteps and checking every corner. The game is every better when played in co-op mode. Interstellar Marines has a long way to go to become a complete and finished project but the potential is there.

PRO's:
- True TFPS atmosphere
- Movement and shooting feel rigid
- Fun co-op and Versus Multiplayer

CON's:
- Inconsistent performance
- Incosistent level of polish
- Overall lack of conent

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Overall, it's an alright sci-fi FPS. The controls are fine, and the game dynamics are generally pretty great. One thing I didn't like was the lack of a objective reviewer or mini-map of somesort. When the next objective is relayed to you by voice, that is the only time you will be briefed on what you should do. If you failed to hear it, well, tough luck. You'll have to guess your way to the next objective.

The different game modes are amusing enough. Elimination and coop provide extra entertainment and even the single player campaigns are worth playing through. The Neurogen episode is a particular favorite, as it incoroporates a certain horror element into the game. Everything is generally pitch black and you are left with just your torch to guide you through much of the game. But the best part is the psychotic androids which have gone berserk and are running around aimlessly throughout the corridors and rooms of the space ship. The sound effects help greatly, to instill a tiny sense of fear, mainly of the 'unknown'. The footsteps of the androids seem frantic at times and hearing them improved the atmosphere. When the androids see you they often run off to hide behind something and wait for you to come closer. Then they charge you with everything they have. It's great.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

10/10 a 'demo' with great potential

I'll make this brief and simple and to the point, okay?
Okay
Interstellar Marines is a game that I found, upon playing it, has a wonderful amount of charm and potential.
Yes, the weapons are currently limmited to the standard SMG and the Assault Rifle, and yes, there's not a whole ton of REAL missions in the singleplayer (by REAL I mean The NeuroGen Incident and the Starcrown Assault), which brings me to my main point of the game.
It's not finished...
When I look at this game, I think of it as more of a Singleplayer/Muliplayer/Co-Op, tactical, space, first person shooter demo.
So if you want to buy this game, I say 'Go for it'.
Just keep in mind that this game is unfinished, and that I cannot be held responsible should anything go to crap, okay?
Okay
P.S. If you've made it all the way down here, I appreciate it, and will let you know that you can find both Valve and 20th Century Fox references within the NeuroGen Incident. Simply listen closely to the station's announcement system, and you'll find them :3

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Quite frankly, I first bought this game after following the updates and I wanted to play it because it added something new to the genre. I played it for a bit with my mate, after getting the spearhead edition for cheap and two keys, we only played multiplayer and was fun for a while. After an hour I got a bit bored becuase it was very slow paced considering the amount of players (4). But with these new updates, I have to say, it might be the best horror experience I've played. It's not intended to be a horror, at least I don't think so, but may I say this game is incredible for that. Playing the neurogen experience for the first time with my friend, we we're both shaking by the end and loved absolutely every second. Hearing a robot in the next room means any loud actions and you're done. The robots spriting at you is incredibly tense and makes me too scared to go around the next corner!!!

For a fantastic tactical FPS game with a group of friends, a singleplayer horror experience or a visceral co-op game to hear your friends scream over skype, this game is perfect for you.

9/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In it's current state, I DO NOT reccommend this game. However, based on what the devolpers have planned and how frequently the updates are coming along I think it will be a good game in the long run. Let's get to the Pro's and Con's of the game so far. {I PLAN TO UPDATE IT}

===PRO===
1. The game looks great and runs great, even on some of the lowest settings. The enviroment changes really do add to the combat experience.
2. Immersion. The devolpers have been trying to make this game really immersive, and they really have. The rain on the helmet, the ambient sounds, everything about the immersion is great. Once the Oculus Rift support for this game arrives, this will be a MUST-OWN for anyone with an Oculus Rift
3. Planned features. This may not seem like a real Pro, but the features the developers want to add sound great. Land Sharks, need I say more?

===CON===
1. Only one gun. Gets very boring using the same gun (THOUGH IT IS IN ALPHA, AN EARLY ALPHA). No sidearms, no melee, just your one SMG.
2. No hit markers, and the gun feels like it does no damage. Kinda feels like shooting at ghosts until they fall over.
3. Only 2 gamemodes (yet again, it's early alpha) Free For All (feels like CoD with one gun) and Team Domination. Team Domination is great mode because it forces teams to work together to hold areas. Sometimes however...
4. TEAM KILLING! Your team mates are only marked with little blue lights. Sometimes it can be hard to see if someones on your team, exspecially if they open fire on you.

Not gonna rant on how there's no melee or crouching yet in the game, because, once more, it's EARLY ALPHA!

In short, Interstellar Marines in it's current state isn't great, but hopefully in a few months it will be well worth the $15.

Early Access Review

Still in very early stages and with somewhat limited content, but very beautiful and very promising. A good tactical shooter with a very strong emphasis on visuals and environment. The maps are beautiful and interesting, offering different tactical challenges and opportunities. Still some performance optimizations planned apparently, although it works excellent on my NVIDIA GTX 760 card running under Linux, and for an Early Access game it seems to be relatively bug free.

The biggest thing that sets this apart from other shooters is the use of the changing lighting and weather effects to create quickly changing scenarios; and it's so satisfying to just flip on your flashlight and open fire on an unsuspecting enemy in the dark.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Lh_W-pSMgPE

BACKGROUND
Indie developers at Zero Point Software were kind enough to share with me a review copy for Interstellar Marines, for which I am very appreciative.

Though it’s worth noting, as a brief aside, that a free copy does not necessarily elicit a flattering review – just see my Qora video for proof of that.

As always, I’ve gone into the game with little to no knowledge of the game or its mechanics, and given it a solid hour’s worth of play time in order to develop some first impressions of the title.
I had never heard of this game until the beginning of the week, but from what I understand, the game in question has been around in some guise or other since about 2005, when the developers involved first sought financial backing, finally hitting Steam Early Access in 2013.

I’m yet to decide exactly how I feel about the growing Early Access phenomenon. While it does operate akin to a long-term beta test, providing a customer base with an opportunity to give direct feedback and guide a game’s development, I feel uncomfortable with the need for financial outlay – particularly when a game can take a good many years to put together, running the risk of developers losing interest and moving on to other things.

Although set to feature a single player and co-op campaign comprised of four distinct acts, telling the story of man’s first contact with sentient life, all that’s been produced over the past nine years are four proof-of-concept demos and a mission entitled The NeuroGen Incident. Being a small outfit that, at this point in time is predominantly crowdfunded, it’s unclear whether the game will ever reach the high bar it’s set itself.

Based on my short playthrough of the NeuroGen mission, however, I very much hope it does.

NARRATIVE
Without any backstory, the mission drops you on un-named ship somewhere out in the depths of space. Everything around you is bathed in darkness, leaving you dependent on your torch’s narrow beam of light to navigate your way into the bowels of the ship and get the power up and running.
The mission itself is simple: to retrieve some research data and destroy all records. Although it’s unclear what the research is or why it needs to be destroyed, there are some strong Weyland-Yutani vibes -- of people in power having meddled in things they don’t fully understand.
Scrambling around in the darkness, crawling through claustrophobic air ducts, trying to bring the ship back to life, faint sounds of movement begin to echo all around you and a tense atmosphere begins to develop, the ship empty, apparently abandoned without warning but for the perpetual movement of faceless androids concealed within a shadowy labyrinth of tunnels.
It’s unclear whether they are friend or foe, showing little to no notice of you whatsoever provided you keep your distance. Antagonise them, however, and you have to act immediately. These things are fast, unpredictable and deadly. Think of the anthropomorphic androids from I, Robot and you’re pretty much there. You never know when they’re going to come for you, but when they do, you’d better be ready. They really are terrifying.

The ambiance for this mission was completely spot on in my book, and left me on edge throughout the entire playthough. It really did take me back to the first third of the very first Half Life game, venturing unaccompanied into a dangerous unknown, trying to piece together events for which you have only the smallest fragments of information. Stuff the co-op option, playing this thing alone is definitely the way to go.

GAMEPLAY
I’ve seen people complain that the androids themselves are too powerful, killing you in just one or two hits. In my view, this is exactly how this kind of game should be. It makes them dangerous, puts you on the back foot, forces you to be cautious and plan your movements. Run and gun this ♥♥♥♥ and you’re in for a bad time.

As for guns, in my playthrough, all you have available is the very sub-machine gun you start off with. Now, some people might bemoan being unable to pick from hundreds of different shotguns and rocket launchers, with the developers themselves planning to eventually release 27 different weapons, but I liked the simplicity of it. The situation will no doubt change as new levels and environments get added, but on a small and enclosed ship, there was no need for anything more. And, as daft as it sounds playing a sci-fi video game, it added to the realism of the thing and maintained a pervasive feeling of vulnerability.

VISUALS
The visuals themselves are nothing special, but they don’t have to be. I’m a firm believer that, if the narrative and gameplay are sound, how a game looks should have very little do with your enjoyment of a game. That was very much the case here. After getting sucked in, creeping panicked around corners, inching deeper and deeper into the ship, the last thing on my mind was the lack of high-res textures and dynamic lighting and advanced particle effects.

FUTURE DEVELOPMENT
Two points of note I will make regarding future development: first, when riding platforms that move vertically, the player’s character bobs up and down, as though clipping in and out of the platform’s floor. I’ve even seen mention elsewhere of people falling right through these platforms, so definitely looks like something the developers need to take a look at. In addition, the game seems to be pretty poorly optimised at present. Although I don’t have the fastest gaming PC in the world, the game was averaging around 15 FPS for much of my playthrough.

FINAL THOUGHTS
Those issues aside, this game was a very pleasant surprise. Though short and still far from finished, this small little taster holds a lot of promise. If the developers stick to their guns and play this right, Interstellar Marines could will be a worthwhile successor to System Shock. Watch this space and cross your fingers.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A note: The game is still in PRE-ALPHA at the time of my review.


The game is still in a very basic state. It's mostly a quick paced run n' gun game right now. You get one weapon, infinite ammo, and with no jump or crouch at the moment, sprinting and trying to strafe yourself out of harms way is the norm right now.

Though later the game is going to a larger variety of weapons, realistic features (such as helmet malfunction), and the basics of crouch and jump.

The game is a simulation of what is may be like to be a marine in a far off future. The marines hud is well designed and can be brought up, which puts your hearing at a disadvantage. They also have some pretty hand gear that can be attached or taken off in the heat of battle, such as a laser and flashlight. Though, I believe the neatest feature of the game is it's changing levels. During gameplay the level will change through several different evironmental effects. For instance, in a marsh, it will be sunny, then a fog may come down, then it may turn to night. Night in this game is very dark. Your flashlight is actually usefull for the purpose of running around otherwise complete darkness.

There are also going to be a few courses to train the marines. Bullseye and running man are two that are going to come to the live game in time. For now, these two game modes are on the official site.


As a conclusion, I think Interstellar marines is worth the 15 dollar price tag. For a game that still has so far to go, it's a fun time even in it's current state. The game will increase in price as it is furthur developed, so even if you're unsure, grabbing it while it is at it's cheapest may be a good idea.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Quite frankly, I first bought this game after following the updates and I wanted to play it because it added something new to the genre. I played it for a bit with my mate, after getting the spearhead edition for cheap and two keys, we only played multiplayer and was fun for a while. After an hour I got a bit bored becuase it was very slow paced considering the amount of players (4). But with these new updates, I have to say, it might be the best horror experience I've played. It's not intended to be a horror, at least I don't think so, but may I say this game is incredible for that. Playing the neurogen experience for the first time with my friend, we we're both shaking by the end and loved absolutely every second. Hearing a robot in the next room means any loud actions and you're done. The robots spriting at you is incredibly tense and makes me too scared to go around the next corner!!!

For a fantastic tactical FPS game with a group of friends, a singleplayer horror experience or a visceral co-op game to hear your friends scream over skype, this game is perfect for you.

9/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In it's current state, I DO NOT reccommend this game. However, based on what the devolpers have planned and how frequently the updates are coming along I think it will be a good game in the long run. Let's get to the Pro's and Con's of the game so far. {I PLAN TO UPDATE IT}

===PRO===
1. The game looks great and runs great, even on some of the lowest settings. The enviroment changes really do add to the combat experience.
2. Immersion. The devolpers have been trying to make this game really immersive, and they really have. The rain on the helmet, the ambient sounds, everything about the immersion is great. Once the Oculus Rift support for this game arrives, this will be a MUST-OWN for anyone with an Oculus Rift
3. Planned features. This may not seem like a real Pro, but the features the developers want to add sound great. Land Sharks, need I say more?

===CON===
1. Only one gun. Gets very boring using the same gun (THOUGH IT IS IN ALPHA, AN EARLY ALPHA). No sidearms, no melee, just your one SMG.
2. No hit markers, and the gun feels like it does no damage. Kinda feels like shooting at ghosts until they fall over.
3. Only 2 gamemodes (yet again, it's early alpha) Free For All (feels like CoD with one gun) and Team Domination. Team Domination is great mode because it forces teams to work together to hold areas. Sometimes however...
4. TEAM KILLING! Your team mates are only marked with little blue lights. Sometimes it can be hard to see if someones on your team, exspecially if they open fire on you.

Not gonna rant on how there's no melee or crouching yet in the game, because, once more, it's EARLY ALPHA!

In short, Interstellar Marines in it's current state isn't great, but hopefully in a few months it will be well worth the $15.

The developers have now added campaign and coop missions which plays unlike a typical FPS game.

It would be perfect , if this game get a proper story-telling campaign mode and more contents. Keep the good work up, developers!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tried out the game on the free weekend, have the following thoughts:

Someone was complaining in a negative review that the free weekend was the stupidest marking decision they could have made. That is just complete and utter garbage. Especially for early access games there should always be a free weekend if for nothing else but to simply let people try the game in the current state.

But in addition to that, and regarding the comment about it being the stupidest decision, all I can say is that steam seems to promote some games and burry others. The fact that this one got a whole free week was a great boost for them I am sure. Hopefully this boost will push the development to the next level, and hopefully the devs can add some critical features to the game and address some of the issues which I will outline below.

After playing the game for most of the free week I have the following observations in no particular order:

Character Control – overall as good as can be expected with the exception of jumping. Your player just feels weighted down. Maybe this is intended, but I found myself frustrated with the lack of fluidity and height in the jump. I would like to see it be where you can jump over some of the cover items in the game such as the concrete barriers and such. And do this in the heat of combat. As it is now, it’s just not very natural feeling and cumbersome. Because of this I rarely even use jump in the game.

Gameplay – A nice variety of mission types with some interesting features. First time I played on a level where the entire area had parts that would raise and lower opening new paths and blocking pervious paths it gave me pause and I had to stop for a minute to marvel at it. Makes for some very tough tactical situations. I like the elimination missions in coop the most, but once you play them a few times it gets stale as you learn where many of the bots spawn from and quickly develop a strategy to beating them, alone or as a team. Not much else in the game at the moment other than bots and not sure if this is by design or because it’s simply not implemented yet but you have infinite ammo. Still have to reload, but you never run out. Still looking for the role play and rainbow-6 tactical elements, but maybe it’s too early for that stuff. The stealth element seems to work well for the most part. Stay low and in the shadows and the bots seem to overlook you. Fire your weapon without a silencer and they will come running to your position. The bots also can home in on you by spotting your flashlight and laser pointer, so you need to know when to use them and when not to.

Coop – This is the area that I would really like to see improved the most. I have two major complaints here. 1) absolutely no recourse for griefers and during the time I have played there have been many, many little sh!ts that have nothing better to do than to f-up your game. That and the ♥♥♥♥♥♥s who want to come in and hijack the server you are playing on. I know they said this is coming but come on, at least give us a group kick vote option or something in the meantime. 2) coop needs more elements to encourage team work. As of now, you get no points for reviving a teammate and communication is terrible. The few people who I have heard using a mic it was terrible, and chat totally blows. Why would you make your chat screen have to be opened with a key press and then cover the entire field of view? The chat interface needs a complete overhaul and we need team quick commands. That would be a good start to making it more tactical. If they want to do something original, give us hand signal animations that we can map to the number keys or something. That would really make stealth tactical. I would also like to see a post-game summary. As of now, when the mission is done, you don't get to see anything.

Levels - Some people complained about how dark some of the levels are. Yes it’s dark and in some cases I think they take it to the extreme, but it definitely makes the levels interesting and challenging in some cases. I hope the light balancing will be tweaked to be more fun and less frustrating in some cases, but over all its not terrible. The bots don’t like it either; it makes it harder to see you!

Content – Aside from the static décor and the bots there’s really nothing else in the game yet. There are interactive doors, some power switches you need to turn on for some missions and lights that you can shoot out. I hope things are added such as ammo, first aid items, of course different weapons, and the typical things you would expect in a shooter. Oh and there is also some background chatter on the intercom, as well as a female voice that gives you some mission instructions from time to time. Interesting to note, it seems like some of the intercom chatter might be alluding to events we might actually see in the finished game. That would be cool.

Weapons – As many people have already said, the weapons that are in the game are pretty good, handle well and cover long range and CQB combat. Nothing special here.

All in all the game has potential. I have heard that it has been in development for a long time, something like 2 years, so it seems to be going slow. I hope the pace picks up. I do recommend the game if you like the genre and the setting, but I’m not gonna go full fantard and try to convince you that they have all these fabulous features planned all you have to do is wait for it. I really don’t know what’s going to come of this game, but while it’s on sale, why not. I am sure I, as well as you, have wasted more on less so give it a shot… maybe the extra cash will help them realize the potential of this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game's dynamic shifts would probably stand out as the main bullet point of the back of the Interstellar Marine box. It changes everything. Suddenly the rain is teaming down, thudding off the helmet of your suit, meaning that running suddenly becomes viable, your loud footsteps masked by the sound of the rain. As the simulation changes again the rain might stop, but the light might abandon you. When it does players are forced to use flashlights for navigation, but open themselves, and their locations, up to attack.

It’s this single mindedness that marks Interstellar Marines out as more than just a standard first person shooter. This doesn’t feel like a game that is going to ♥♥♥ superfluous nonsense to it to draw in a crowd of Call of Duty gamers. Granted, not doing so could be detrimental to the game’s sales, but, as with the game itself, sticking to their guns and being deliberate in both message and content could attract a dedicated and loyal base.

http://www.coffeebreakgaming.co.uk/pc-games/early-access-investigations-interstellar-marines/

reviewText:
Early Access Review

How do I think of interstellar marines?

This is a good game. That is the easiest way to put it. You get into two team into a battlefield/arena. And similar to counterstrike you have one life. The exception to this one life rule is you can respawn in 200+ seconds or capture a point. The round is usually over in two minutes (with the exception of games that go backwards and forwards) so the only way to really give you team an advantage is to capture the points.

What else is great about this game?

One of my favourite things about it in the day/night cycles and lighting. Most maps outside have a day and night cycle which changes how you have to play. It's to dark to see anything so you have to use a flashlight but the enemy can pinpoint where you are from the flashlight. You have to play stealthily other wise it's gameover. This goes the same for lazer pointers in daytime. Indoor maps usually have three modes. The light are on normally, There is a red alarm or there are no lights. I find these all brilliant features which change the way you play every now and then.

And extra thing that i like about this game!

Well the fact the developers put the time and effort into letting you be able to take your mask off is amazing. It is a little feature but it is great fun when a couple of friends and i jump into an empty lobby and take your mask off. It has given us a few laughs like *friendly Fire* and *lucky shots* This game just keeps me coming back for more.

The minor thing about this game is the population of it. You will occasionally find a full lobby and a couble of half lobbies but the rest of it is dead. The main reason for that is probably early access and I hope the population grows.

(I probably missed some stuff out in this review.. I apologize)

In the end I give this game a 9/10 It is great fun. especially with friends!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Now you might be thinking to yourself, how can you give this game a positive review already?

For many reasons

- I had always kept myself on check looking around EVERY corner that i passed.
- Had to actually stay with other squad mates to finish the objectives.
- Great intro to the game, it just throws you in for your first life. (It is a lot better than it sounds)
- Great Co-op experience.
- Also, what AAA developers are missing way too much of, seeing your own feet
- Sounds are great, but a bit more ambience to levels would be nice

There are a few things that i want added to the game, few of which I am pretty sure that are going to be added to the first place.

- Leaning
- More weapons and possibly loadout menu
- Melee attack of some sort
- An actual tutorial (right now it only takes you to a youtube playlist)
- More control customizations (Non-Toggle Sprint, one click ADS on/off, hold down click ADS on/off instead of bieng both on at once)
- PVP Multiplayer ( I know this is Co-Op but this would be a nice addon to the game, i can see it compete against Insurgency's Multiplayer)
- More graphics options
- A larger penalty for players for team killing

Although at the current state (Beta 1.6) this game seems more promising than DAYZ right now. And for this being a Unity game, this looks and feels really nice! I am looking forward towards seeing what else this developing company has to offer!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nJust excellent. Ever been bothered by predictable A.I, or games that are 'set in their ways?' Up to now, there has been little predictability in this game, which makes it the most interesting shooter I have ever played. Camping means countermeasures by very intelligent A.I.'s, which work together constantly to close in on their target: You! Which means you must do everything you can to convince them you are not there. If one cannot learn to work as a team and understand how much communication, routine, persistance, adaptation and covering each other is needed, well, the adversary does! And that is just part one of this still developing game, which is promising indeed. Up 'till now, I have only played against the Combat Robots. You will fear them. You will grow to hate them. Their sound, look and zombie-like behaviour. That's ok, they really seem to hate organic intelligence too. You will thoroughly enjoy gunning down each and every one of them, which is another thing you have in common with them. In fact, it doesn't feel right to leave one standing. Even though you are a badass marine, somehow you will understand and appreciate a certain BeeGee's -song. You will scream, you will run, and you will cry, which is why this game is best played with friends in CO-OP. After all, aren't friends the people you share laughter, despair and your vulnerabilities with? And just to be clear, this game is not for people who believe in 'health-bars', cool guns vs. effective guns, or fair game. You're the game. Fair enough. This will make you experience the future of shooter games. Because that is exactly what it is. That, and the end of noobism.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a truly good game.  This is an alpah review as of 09/06/2014 so things will change.

It feels, and I dare say this, like a futuristic cs:source.

The weapons take presicion to handle and it doesn't take more than a couple of well placed rounds to take you out.  The respawn time is punishing, it varies based on how well your team is doing and sometimes you might just have to wait out the round.

The graphics aren't anything crazy, but they look pretty good.  The weather, rain and wind, are amazing!  So are the sounds!  The darkness of the levels is really fun too.  It teaches you to pay attention to where you move.

This game is good.  I hope that it does leave alpha stage and makes some good money because it has so many cool ideas that haven't really been done before.

Robotit ovat ottaneet vallan tukikohdassa ja teloittaneet muut ihmiset ja jäljelle jää pelaaja ja sen pelaaja tukijoukot.

Pelaajan on tarkoitus esimerkiksi palauttaa sähköt ja voimalähteet tukikohtaan voidakseen tuhota vastustajansa, mutta alueella vartioi terminaatoreita, joilla on aseistusta.

Pelaajan täytyy yrittää selvitä henkissä tehtävistä ja käyttää ympäristöä hyväksi sekä hiippailla ja tarvittaessa käyttää yhteisöpelaaja tukijoukkoja hyväksi ettei tule itse ammutuksi.

Suositteluni. :3

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Even for a game that's in it's pre alpha stages, it's a very good game. Don't get me wrong. Like all games in existence, this game has it's fair share of problems. You really can't expect much from a game that's currently in alpha, or pretty much ANY game at all since every game as I've stated before has their own set of issues.

As of right now, the game is very lackluster and barebones, but again, you really can't expect too much from an alpha, so have caution if you're expecting this game to give you a lot because as of right now, there's not too much for this game to offer at the moment in it's current stage considering it's an early access title.

Another issue I've come across, which I'm still confused on determining what exactly the issue is that's causing this. Regardless, hit detection is another issue (when I'm not in U.S. servers). Any combination of these three reasons could be the cause: Netcode issue, tickrate issue, server location. But again, since it IS an alpha title, I can't really expect it to be perfect considering this game has been in the works slowly for the past decade, which definitely tells you how much the developers care if they're taking their time to perfect their game.

One other issue is engine optimization. The graphics, while great, are also very simple, and with simple graphics, I shouldn't be having such huge FPS fluxuations with my FPS dropping as low as 10 FPS at times. Now, the prototypes of the different game modes on the official Interstellar Marines website (especially Bullseye, which ran at a solid 60 FPS for me) looks, sounds, plays, and runs much better than what we currently have on Steam (again, alpha stage, you can't really expect much) which tells me that they're probably taking the DayZ route of things and most likely going to change engines in the future to a more optimized, a more playable engine. Again, it's an alpha. Not only is this game an alpha, but Zero Point Software is an independant game development company. You gotta start somewhere. Gotta be patient with this one considering how careful the devs are being and how delicate they're treating this game. Obviously, this game still has a lot of work to be done, but it's still great nonetheless for an alpha. Pretty much, most of the issues we're seeing currently is due to it's alpha status, which really NO game as an alpha or even a beta can avoid. It's just part of early access games and development. It's natural and it takes time.

Regardless, the game is great, and the prototypes of the different game modes on the official Interstellar Marines website are also fantastic as well, which pretty much gives you a taste or a hint of what's to come with this game in the future.

Although this game has been in development since 2004, I'd rather a game take 10 years to develop just so it can be perfect and up to it's full potential as opposed to having a broken game released to me that clearly isn't finished yet *coughcoughBADCOMPANY2coughcoughCALLOFDUTYcoughcoughBATTLEFIELD4*.

With that being said, I'd really suggest supporting Zero Point Software as much as possible considering they've been busting their asses off for the past 10 years just to dish out a good game, and that right there tells you that these developers take this seriously and pour every ounce of their tears and blood into this game.

Get this game. If not now as an pre alpha, get it as a full release when it's finally complete.

UPDATE: As of now, many of these issues I mentioned earlier have been resolved by the devs, all the more reason to get this game seeing as the devs actually give a ♥♥♥♥ about their game.
